NAME: Field testing and measuring in sport
TEACHERS: Lipčák, A. - Vencúrik, T.
SYLLABUS:
Thematic units:
    - introduction to testing and measurement theory,
    - standardized tests, test systems and measurement recording,
    - tests of coordination abilities (reaction rate, balance,orientation, kinetic-differentiation ability) and flexibility,
    - strength and power tests (static and dynamic force, explosive force),
    - speed abilities tests (acceleration speed, frequency, maximum speed),
    - tests aimed at change of direction speed and agility,
    - tests on the ability of repeated sprints,
    - endurance tests (anaerobic endurance and aerobic endurance),
    - processing and evaluation of data obtained from testing and measurement,
    - interpretation and comparison of data obtained from testing and measurement.
OBJECTIVES: To gain knowledge about basic measurement methods and construction of field tests and how to use them to acquire the skills and experience needed for measuring and testing in physical education and sport.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Basic knowledge from anthropomotorics (bp4018) and methodology of sport science (bp4001).
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. 80% attendance,
    2. e-learning test,
    3. practical demonstration of students from testing and measuring in a selected sport
    4. report from testing session
TEACHING_METHODS:
Practical seminars where students will perform selected tests.
    Self-study.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After successfully completing the course student will:
    - have basic knowledge of field test theory and measurement,
    - know the difference between standardized and non-standardized tests,
    - be able to choose a suitable standardized test for motor ability testing,
    - know the procedure of standardized tests of coordination abilities and will be able to use it in practice,
    - know the procedure of standardized tests of strength and conditioning abilities and will be able to use it in practice,
    - have knowledge of motor skills tests,
    - know testing systems for fitness assessment,
    - be able to evaluate the risks of testing and measurement, and will be able to identify factors that may influence test performance,
    - have an overview of the instruments and devices used for testing and measurement,
    - be able to record, process and evaluate the data obtained from testing and measurement,
    - be able to interpret acquired data and compare it with standards and data from other research.
LITERATURE:
Essentials of strength training and conditioning. Edited by Greg Haff - N. Travis Triplett. Fourth edition. Champaign, Ill.: Human Kinetics, 2016, xvi, 735. ISBN 9781492501626. info
        MORROW, James R., Dale MOOD, James G. DISCH a Minsoo KANG. Measurement and evaluation in human performance. Fifth edition. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics, 2016, xv, 463. ISBN 9781450470438. info

NAME: Sports Psychology and Working with Clients
TEACHERS: Pačesová, P. - Kubíčková, V.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bk4017 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS: Sport psychology, historical development, recent situation. psychologie sportu • Professiography, psycho-sportography. Laterality. • Personality of the athlete, diagnostic process, classification. Temperament. • Motivation, basic theories. Need for achievement. Assessment. Aspiration. • Characteristics, features, dynamic development. Social influence: innovation, conformity, authority, decision making. Stages of the group development. The regulations, norms. • Individual and the team. Roles. Leader. • Executive functions, motor intellect. • Psyche and top achievement. Self-awareness, the goals, activation - relaxation. • Psyche and top achievement. stress, fear, anxiety and competition. Emotion, aggression, dynamic processes and sports. • Motor learning, specific theories. Faces, plato, process of the forgetting. Flow. Asertivity and sports activities. • Advising: definition, principles, approaches: consulting, manipulative, directive. - Meeting client: legislation, the goal, diagnostic process, SMART technique. - Communication: talking - hearing, questioning, interview, solving of model situations. -Self-reflection. - Principles of spiritual hygiene.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to reserve the basic information focuses on psychology knowledge into sport setting: recreation, top competitive, physical education. The aim is oriented on issues linked with psychical processes in mentioned environment within dyadic and team network, on the topics: professional, motor competencies etc. Next aim is to underline the topics of the individual approaches to individuals from different social groups and in various life situations, issue of consulting, interactive approaches to client.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Passing subject bpo4017 Psychology
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 80% participation on interactive seminars - 8 homeworks, written, ppt, - written test - open questions, 60% of the successful answers, with discussiom and feedback
TEACHING_METHODS: theoretical lectures, seminars, class discussion, self-work oriented on self-reflexion, presentation
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After the course student is able to - use the knowledge in the field practice, - to analyze the personality features and behavior (athlete, coach), - recognize learning processes and motor learning, - demonstrate the regulation of psychic level in relation in sports loading, - to solve conflict situation in the team, - to analyze psychical needs of the individual and his/her goals, - to presents communicative skills in relation on client situation, - to cope, solve the individual problems within sports and healthy life style environment.

NAME: Patophysiology of Exercise
TEACHERS: Bernaciková, M. - Kapounková, K. - Bernaciková, M. - Řehoř, A.
SYLLABUS:
Syllabus of lectures:
    Fundamentals of genetics (genetic code, replication, transcription and translation of DNA, chromosomes). DNA diagnostics.
    Pathophysiology of cell and cell interactions (apoptosis, necrosis, disease factors).
    General manifestations of disease (fever, pain, inflammation).
    Pathophysiology of stress (fatigue).
    Acidobasic equilibrium disorders.
    Disorders of carbohydrate metabolism (DM).
    Disorders of lipid metabolism (hyperlipoproteinemia, hypolipoproteinemia). Pathophysiology of atherosclerosis.
    Disorders of nucleotide metabolism (arthritis uratica, tumor breakdown syndrome). Disorders of hem and iron metabolism.
    Consequences of hypokinesia. Some systemic manifestations of lack of physical activity.
    Metabolic syndrome (definitions, signs, causes of onset).
    Dysregulation of food intake and body weight (with negative energy balance, positive energy balance).
    Acute damage in sports. Types of injuries. causes and mechanisms of injuries in sport due to the specificities of selected sports disciplines.
    Chronic damage in sports.
    Syllabus of exercises:
    Influence of genetics on physical activity and obesity (human genome, sports genes, obesity genes, epigenetics, genetic tests etc.).
    Influenced biological factors of preanalytical variability in biochemical sampling (race, sex, genetic factors, pregnancy, biorhythms, weight, lifestyle, physical load, diet, smoking).
    Biochemical markers of inflammation (C-reactive protein, cytokines).
    Biological indicators of fatigue. Questionnaire for fatigue manifestations (physiological + psychological) + its evaluation.
    Subjective feelings, speaking test (practically).
    Biochemical indicators of acid-base balance disorders (buffer systems, BE, PH, PO2, pCO2).
    Selected stress tests and monitoring of physiological functions of carbohydrate metabolism disorders (oral glucose tolerance test - oGTT, monitoring of glycemia in motion activity - glucometers, biosensors).
    Monitoring of physiological functions in lipid metabolism disorders (cholesterol, triacylglycerols, adiponectin, ghrelin, leptin). Ultrasound.
    Metabolic syndrome - risk factors (anthropometric indicators, blood pressure measurements, biochemical indicators).
    Anthropometric indicators (fat component, muscle component, bone density).
    Risk analysis of injuries in relation to sports disciplines. Prevention principles.
    Physical activity during pregnancy (recommendation) and postpartum (including diastase and umbilical hernia - practical demonstration).
    Physiology and pathophysiology of running on runway and outdoors - practically.
    Physiology and pathophysiology during treadmill and bicycle trekking. - practically
OBJECTIVES: The graduate will be able to understand the basic physiological and pathological processes of people with sedentary lifestyles. The graduate will also be able to think creatively about the possible consequences of physical activity on the human body. Not only in the field of biological effects on individual systems, but also in the area of possible pathophysiological impact of regular specific sports load (both acute and chronic).
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 90% active participation in exercises. Student graduates. - 2 written tests. tests consist of   10 questions rated 20 points. To achieve successful mastery, it is necessary to achieve 14. - the working sheets drawn up and handed over. The whole subject is finished by an oral exam, evaluated by the A-F scale.
TEACHING_METHODS: Lecture and practice. Exercises are both theoretical and practical, including laboratory testing. Teaching methods: presentation, discussion, demonstration of tests, practical measurements, homework (replenishment of worksheets).
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
The graduate will be able to:
    1. explain the issue of hypokinesis in relation to possible system changes of the organism and their health consequences
    2. recommend basic stress and biochemical examinations in relation to possible weakness resulting from   hypokinesia
    3. to list and describe possible injuries and typical chronic injuries in selected sports disciplines
LITERATURE:
OTOVÁ, Berta a František SOUKUP. Základy genetiky (Obsaž.) : Biologie člověka pro bakalářské studium na lékařských fakultách. info

NAME: Kinesiology
TEACHERS: Bazalová, P. - Ševčíková, B. - Vysoký, R.
SYLLABUS:
Motor control - cortical, subcortical and spinal level. Basic techniques of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation and inhibition.
    Kinesiology of soft tissues of locomotor apparatus - skin, subdermal tissue, fascia, muscle, cartilage.
    Kinesiology of hard tissues of locomotor apparatus - bone.
    Kinesiology of upper extremity - basic motor patterns
    Kinesiology of lower extremity - basic motor patterns
OBJECTIVES: The aim of Kinesiology lectures is to introduce students to human locomotor system from the perspective of motor control and soft and hard tissues of locomotor system itself. Motor control is presented as multi level from cortical control towards spinal incl. ontogenesis of gross and fine motorics. Human motor system is also explained from the topographical point as particular motor segments incl. physiology of adaptation and maladaptation to work load. Global postural reactions and movement patterns are axplained.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 2 written tests in the course of a term and one final written test. 70% of correct answers is needed to pass.
TEACHING_METHODS: Frontal type of education with open discussion to presented topics.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Successful students will achieve basic knowledge of motor control incl. optional therapeutical interventions. They will know mechanisms of adaptation and maladaptation of motor tissues to work load. Students will understand basic topographic anatomy and physiology of particular motor segments of human body.
LITERATURE:
KAPANDJI, Adalbert Ibrahim. The physiology of the joints. 6th ed. Edinburgh: Churchill Livingstone, 2011, ix, 323. ISBN 9780702039423. info

NAME: Strength Training and Conditioning in Individual Sports
TEACHERS: Cacek, J. - Králová, T. - Kalina, T. - Hrubý, M. - Roček, M. - Mojžíš, M. - Králová, T. - Kalina, T.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_kondcvic )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    Specifics of strength and conditional training in individual sports.
    Strength and conditional training in short-term lasting functionally mobilizing sports. (sprints, throws, shot put, weight lifting).
    Strength and conditional training in long term lasting functionally mobilizing sports. (cycling, long distance running).
    Strength and conditional training in risks sports. (skiing, bobsled).
    Strength and conditional training in anticipation sports. (martial arts, fencing, tennis)
    Strength and conditional training in aesthetic- coordination sports (gymnastic).
    Strength and conditional training in senzory sports. (golf).
    Recomendation for physical activity in common population.
    Monitoring of fitness and physical activity in common population.
    Seminars:
    Preparation of training plans for selected individual sports.
    Preparation of motion programs for common population.
    evidence of training and physical activity of common population.
    Examples of excersises, methods, development and stabilization, of specific training in individual selected sports
    Examples of excersises, methods of development and stabilization of fitness in common population.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of subject is provide knowledge about specifics of strength and coditional training in selected sports with development of physical fitness. The another goal is to educate students with planning, periodization and leading of conditional training in selected groups.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Completion of subject Periodization and planning of training.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The exam consists of two parts.
    The first part is the preparation (individual, group work) of plans for training units, microcycles, mesocycles or macrocycles in a specified sport discipline or selected population group (the distribution of specific topics will take place during the first week of the semester). Students will upload the developed topic to the appropriate drop box no later than 2 days prior to the specific due date determined at the beginning of the semester. They then present the developed training plan along with the basic background of fitness training for the topic/sport/population and demonstrate the selected training unit in the seminar. The preparation and implementation of the identified plan and training unit A-F is assessed. The seminar output assessment accounts for 30% of the overall course grade.
    The second part is a written and subsequent oral examination in which the student draws one of the individual sports. For this sport, the student will describe the background of fitness training and design training plans according to the assignment, which he/she will defend orally immediately after the written preparation. The examination grade is A-F, with the examination accounting for 70% of the overall grade for the course.
TEACHING_METHODS: Theory and practical excersises, planning motion and training programs.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After succesfull of the subject student will be able to:
    to interprete basic of planning and periodization of strength and conditional training in individual sports.
    to apply structure of sports perfomance factors on concrete sports perfomance in selected sports or disciplines.
    to realize plans of strength and conditional training in common population and in selected spotrs.

NAME: Olympic Weightlifting
TEACHERS: Králová, T.
SYLLABUS:
Introduction to excersise with olympic bar, manipulation with dumbells and loading dumbells on bar, rules.
    Safety and individual help.
    squat with olympic bar (front, back, with help, up).
    Basic position at individual weightlifting excersises.
    Methods of snatch training.
    Methods of clean and jerk training.
    Nomenclature of weightlifting excersises.
    Theoretical basic of weightlifting excersises.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of subject is educate students about weight-lifting knowledge and skills. (basic of nomenclature, technique of weightlifting, excersise with olympic bar, diagnostic of mistakes and their elimination).
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The credit consists of two parts.
    The first part is a written test (10 questions, 75% correct answers are required to pass, the assessment is pass/fail; the test can be repeated 3 times). The test focuses on weightlifting rules, weightlifting methodology and exercise terminology.
    The second part of the credit consists of a practical demonstration of a competitive execution of a snatch and clean and jerk in a real competition according to the rules of weightlifting. The selected competition will be announced during the first class of the semester. The assessment for the practical credit is pass/fail, where pass means successful completion of the selected competition (in the Olympic weightlifting). The weight of the lowest base for start weight in the competition is limited by the weightlifting rules (women = 21 kg; men 26 kg).
TEACHER_INFO: https://is.muni.cz/do/rect/el/estud/fsps/js18/metodika_vzpirani/web/index.html
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After succesfull completion student will be able:
    to demonstrate technique of snatch and jerk
    to identify mistakes in technique of weightlifting excersises, to propose and suggest procedure of their elimination
    to demonstrate training methodology of snatch and jerk, including with specific, preparatory excersises with olympic bar
    to apply the structure of training weight lifting excersises, including their modifications

OBJECTIVES: Within study of subject compensatory exercises student will practically develop his knowledge in prescription of compensatory exercises as a mean of prevention of acute or chronic disorder of locomotive apparatus caused by long-term lasting overloading or trauma in sport.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Attending of subject is obligatory. Student is required to submit a seminar paper related to methodical scene.The whole subject is finished by graded credits, which is awarded based on attendance, ,seminar paper and student´s activity.
TEACHING_METHODS: Lectures, Class Discussion, Presentation of Methodological Scenes, Homeworks
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    - to perform diagnostic methods of locomotor system necessary to prescribe compensation of unilateral loads in various sports
    - to apply the didactic principles of compensatory exercises
    - to propose an adequate balancing process for various sports
    - to compile a compensation plan within the training process in performance and top sport

NAME: Primary Prevention of Chronic Non-Communicable Diseases
TEACHERS: Kapounková, K. - Vysoký, R. - Kapounková, K. - Vysoký, R.
SYLLABUS:
Overview of lecture topics:
    Health and disease. Definition of health. Definition of illness.
    Basic determinants of health. Health promotion.
    The importance and objectives of prevention in the field of chronic noninfectious diseases
    Stages of disease development and inclusion of all levels of prevention (principle, meaning).
    Lifestyle and the emergence of civilization diseases. Quality of life in relation to health.
    Targeted assistance with regard to specific individual needs.
    System, characteristics and organization of preventive programs (planning, finance).
    Evaluation of preventive programs (short-term and long-term effect of the program).
    World Health Organization (WHO establishment and operation, health programs implemented in the Czech Republic, health 2020)

    Overview of seminar topics:
    Organization of preventive programs (planning, finance, creation of a crisis intervention system).
    Evaluation of preventive programs (short-term and long-term effect of the program).
    Preventive examinations and examinations. Screening examinations in primary care.
    Quality of life in relation to health (evaluation methods).
OBJECTIVES: Course graduates should be able to logically think about prevention as a tool to contribute to the sustainable development of humanity and life. Course graduates should acquire knowledge of the active influence of risk factors for the emergence of civilization diseases.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 90% active participation in seminars • Creation of a preventive health promotion project according to the assignment, evaluated by A-F scale • Oral examination of the quality assessment of the area, assessed by the A-F scale
TEACHING_METHODS: Theoretical and practical lessons in the form of lectures and seminars.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Graduates of the course will be able to:
    1. search for existing prevention programs
    2. Evaluate current prevention programs
    3. evaluate the results of the preventive examinations
    4. Focus on strategic recommendations on health promotion

NAME: Sports Massage
TEACHERS: Müllerová, M. - Struhár, I.
SYLLABUS:
1. Ergonomics of work. Repetition of tactics and assemblies from classic massage (Lower limb massage, back massage including scapula, Massage of the neck including scapula, Massage of the upper limbs, Massage of the abdomen)
    2. Role of masseur in preparation for sports performance
    3. Determination of basic anamnestic data necessary for the realization of massage 4. Measuring range of motion
    5. Communication between a masseur and an athlete in terms of preparing an athlete for performance
    6. Pre-event massage
    7. Massage in breaks between performances
    8. Massage after sport performance and its specifics
    9. Sport massage in speed-power sports
    10. Sport massage in endurance sports
    11. Sports massage in sports games
    12. Sports massage in aesthetic-coordinating and combo sports
    13. Sports injuries and massage applications
OBJECTIVES: The main goal of this course is to provide students practical skills in the field of using sports massage as a means of regeneration. Within the framework of the lessons, we will focus on improving the practical application of the massage strokes from the Classical massage. We will also focus on the art of palpation (both surface and deep). The course is also focused on practical differentiation of soft tissues and palpation.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Successful completion of subjects Classical Massage and Anatomy
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. attendance (one absence is permitted)
    2. 2 tests during semester, min.65 %
    3. Practical exam
TEACHING_METHODS: 1. Theoretical part 2. Practical part focused on the right application of sport massage with correction of qualified practitioner
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    1. to identify the appropriate type of sports massage with regard to goals
    2. to assess the current state of the locomotive system
    3. to explain the choice of the chosen sport massage
    4. to discuss the choice of used tactics in a sports massage
    5. to practice a sports massage before, in a break of unfinished performance and after the completion of the physical activity
    6. to design a regeneration protocol with respect to the athlete's physical load and physical activity
    7. to evaluate the athlete's status based on the subjective feeling before and after the application of the selected type of sports massage
    8. to evaluate the athlete's current readiness for performance in relation to objective parameters such as measuring range of motion
LITERATURE:
MCGILLICUDDY, Michael. Massage for sport performance. Champaign, Ill.: Human Kinetics, 2011, ix, 181. ISBN 9780736083010. info

NAME: Nutritional Counselling
TEACHERS: Hlinský, T. - Kumstát, M.
SYLLABUS:
01. Introduction to nutritional programming
    02. Evolutionary context of nutrition in human health
    03. Medical history
    04. Methods of assessing nutritional status
    05. Qualitative and quantitative aspects of nutrition
    06. Nutritional recommendations
    07. Child nutrition
    08. Nutrition of pregnant and lactating women
    09. Nutrition of the elderly
    10. Role of nutrition and lifestyle in primary prevention
    11. Role of nutrition in secondary and tertiary prevention
    12. Allergies and intolerances
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to introduce students to methods of nutritional status assessment, tools for assessing dietary habits and aspects of counselling. An integral part of nutritional programming, namely planning, is the acquisition of skills not only in dietary analysis but especially in dietary modification, suggesting changes, and interpreting results to clients from different population groups.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Students build on the knowledge acquired in bk4013 Physiology, bk4063 Physiology of Nutrition and bk4062 Nutrition.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Students are graded A-F based on meeting the prerequisites below:
    1. Active participation in seminars (1 absence allowed).
    2. Completion of a portfolio, which is a requirement for admission to the examination, to the following extent:
    a) Semester project in the form of a comprehensive text document according to the template. The content will be an analysis and evaluation of the nutritional status and dietary habits of the selected case study, together with a proposal for recommendations;
    b) completion of the Peer Review of the semester project;
    c) continuous completion of the sub-assigned independent work as assigned in the interactive curriculum.
    3. Interim tests verifying knowledge of the studied areas (3 in total). The tests are taken at the time of the seminar every fourth week of the semester. The maximum number of points obtained in all tests is 30. For credit to be awarded, at least 75% of the maximum score must be obtained (at least 22 points).
    4. Passing the oral examination.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Theoretical support is preferably the content of lectures and independent work - self-study of interactive study aids (in the scope of about 1 hour/week).
    Practical teaching is implemented in the form of seminars with open discussion and thematic workshops. It will include:
    - group work,
    - case study analysis,
    - application of knowledge to work with population groups.
    Independent work based on the seminar teaching will be based on completing homework exercises and assignments, submitting them to the appropriate submission room, and completing answer sheets and course projects involving peer assessment.
LITERATURE:
RAWSON, Eric S., J. David BRANCH a Tammy J. STEPHENSON. Williams' nutrition for health, fitness & sport. Thirteenth edition. New York: McGraw Hill, 2024, 1 online. ISBN 9781266492150. URL info

NAME: Nutritional Counselling in Sport
TEACHERS: Kumstát, M. - Hlinský, T.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to apply and modify aquired knowledge of basic principles of nutrition to the variable sports preparation and competition in an effort to support training adaptation, regeneration and sport performance.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Students are graded A-F based on meeting the prerequisites below:
    1. Active participation in seminars (1 absence allowed).
    2. Completion of a portfolio, which is a requirement for admission to the examination, to the following extent:
    a) Semester project in the form of a comprehensive text document according to the template. The content will be an analysis and evaluation of the nutritional status and dietary habits of the selected case study, together with a proposal for recommendations;
    b) Completion of the Semester Project Peer Review;
    c) continuous completion of the sub-assigned independent work as assigned in the interactive curriculum.
    3. Interim tests verifying knowledge of the studied areas (3 in total). The tests are taken at the time of the seminar every fourth week of the semester. The maximum number of points obtained from all tests is 30. To be awarded credit, at least 75% of the maximum score (at least 22 points) must be obtained.
    4. Passing the oral examination.
TEACHING_METHODS:
The theoretical basis of the subject is primarily delivered through lectures and home-study, including self-directed use of the interactive syllabus (approximately 1 hour per week).
    Practical instruction is conducted through seminars featuring open discussions and thematic workshops. These will involve group work, peer analysis of case studies, and applying findings to work with various athletes. Independent study, building on seminar content, will include completing homework exercises and assignments, submitting them through the designated submission portal, and finishing answer sheets and course projects.

NAME: Athlete Regeneration
TEACHERS: Kapounková, K. - Krajňák, J. - Kumstát, M. - Lipková, L. - Puda, D. - Struhár, I.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    -Regeneration - fundamental concepts
    -Stress reaction
    -Regenerative form
    -Acute and chronic fatique
    -Regenerative pedagogical means
    -Regenerative psychological means
    -Regenerative biological means
    -Regenerative pharmacological means
    -Physiological and pathological fatigue
    -Physiological aspect of the motion
    Seminars:
    -Postural stability and deep stabilization system- injury prevention, practical demonstration
    -Stress testing of the athlete (demonstration of protocols + subsequent analysis of data)
    -Isokinetic testing in relation to sports regeneration
    -Using of compression garments in relation to performance and athlete´s regeneration
    -Influence of negative thermotherapy and its application in sport
    -The use of selected forms of hydrotherapy in athlete´s regeneration
    -Myofascial release with using foamrollers
OBJECTIVES: Main objectives can be summarized as follows: the basic knowledge about regeneration; to delineate the major differences between passive and active regeneration; to understand the physiologic process of organism in the course regeneration; to understand the chronological process of regeneration; to understand the chanching regeneration of the type in the sports motion to make the regeneration plane for athletic discipline
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. Attendance (two absence is permitted)
    2. Regularly preparation at seminars
    3. Test. Test comprises 30 questions. When a student answers a question correctly, he/she is awarded a point for it. To pass the test, the student must reach the score of at least 21 points.
    4. Exam
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    1. to explain the difference between active and passive recovery
    2. to analyse the athlete training loads
    3. to design a suitable type of regeneration for the expected type of fatigue
LITERATURE:
BERNACIKOVÁ, Martina, Jan CACEK, Lenka DOVRTĚLOVÁ, Iva HRNČIŘÍKOVÁ, Kateřina KAPOUNKOVÁ, Jitka KOPŘIVOVÁ, Michal KUMSTÁT, Jan NOVOTNÝ, Petr POSPÍŠIL, Jana ŘEZANINOVÁ, Michal ŠAFÁŘ a Tomáš ULBRICH. Regenerace a výživa ve sportu. 1. vyd. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2013, 252 s. ISBN 978-80-210-6253-5. info

NAME: Sports Psychology and Coaching
TEACHERS: Pačesová, P. - Kubíčková, V.
SYLLABUS: Sport psychology, historical development, recent situation. psychologie sportu • Professiography, psycho-sportography. Laterality. • Personality of the athlete, diagnostic process, classification. Temperament. • Motivation, basic theories. Need for achievement. Assessment. Aspiration. • Sociální skupina a sport - charakteristika, utváření, působení, dynamika Social groups, teams. Characteristics, features, dynamic development. Social influence: innovation, conformity, authority, decision making. Stages of the group development. The regulations, norms. • Individual and the team. Roles. Leader. • Executive functions, motor intellect. • Psyche and top achievement. Self-awareness, the goals, activation - relaxation. • Psyche and top achievement. stress, fear, anxiety and competition. Emotion, aggression, dynamic processes and sports. • Motor learning, specific theories. Faces, plato, process of the forgetting. Flow. Asertivity and sports activities. • Coaching: the goals, principles, means. Dyadic interaction, team interaction. • Team management, atmosphere in the team. Team atmosphere. Team regulations and norms. Personal development of the athletes. Principles of spiritual hygiene.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to reserve the basic information focuses on psychology knowledge into sport setting: recreation, top competitive, physical education. The aim is oriented on issues linked with psychical processes in mentioned environment within dyadic and team network. Next aim is to present the topics from coaching domain as the mean of the development personality and the team.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 80 % - participation in seminars home-works - assessed with points Written test - open questions
TEACHING_METHODS: Interactive lectures with support of IT, seminars, self-study, class discussion.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After the course student is able to - use the knowledge in the field practice, - to analyze the personality features and behavior (athlete, coach), - recognize learning processes and motor learning, - demonstrate the regulation of psychic level in relation in sports loading, - to solve conflict situation in the team, - to analyze team atmosphere, - to apply basic coaching skills.
LITERATURE:
BLAHUTKOVÁ, Marie a Miroslav SLIŽIK. Vybrané kapitoly z psychologie sportu. 1. vyd. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2014, 117 s. ISBN 978-80-210-6691-5. info

NAME: Sports Traumatology
TEACHERS: Vomela, J. - Komzák, M. - Kapounková, K. - Bernaciková, M.
SYLLABUS:
1. Kind of injuries – after body regions, organs and causes
    2. Causes of th injuries in sport (after kind of sport)
    3. Analyse of sports after risks of the injuries
    4. Rules of the prevention of the injuries.
    5. Rules of the non-medical treatment of the injuries, first aids.
    6. Injuries of the locomotion apparatus of the trunc – muscles and tendons
    7. Injuries of the locomotion apparatus of the trunc – bones, periost and joints
    8. Injuries of the locomotoin apparatus of the superior extremities – muscles and tendons
    9. Injuries of the locomotoin apparatus of the superior extremities – bones, periost and joints
    10. Injuries of the locomotoin apparatus of the inferior extremities – muscles and tendons
    11. Injuries of the locomotoin apparatus of the inferior extremities – muscles and tendons
    12. Skin injuries
    13. Injuries of the head and senses
    14. Injuries of the thracic organs, first of all heart and lungs
    15. Injuries of the abdominal organs
OBJECTIVES: To acquire the knowledge on exercise and sport injuries, and to be able to do relevant prevention and first treatment of the injuries.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Knowledge of human anatomy
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Minimally 80% of the seminar presence; oral examination.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Students will be able
    1. to enumerate and describe the possible injuries at the sport training of certain sports or disciplins
    2. to identify causes of the injuries
    3. to propose the relevant prevention
    4. to do relevant non-medical treatment

NAME: Self-Defence 1
TEACHERS: Bugala, M. - Novák, J. - Vít, M. - Kubíčková, V.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_upoly )
SYLLABUS: 1. Definition of self-defence and its place in the taxonomy of combatives 2. Legal aspects of self-defence 3. Preparation and performance in self-defence 4. Principles of self-defence training 5. Psychological preparation in self-defence 6. Strategy and tactics in self-defence 7. Technical means of self-defence 8. Conditioning in self-defence 9. Particularity of self-defence for women 10. Model self-defence situation with all kind of attacks
OBJECTIVES: The course is an introduction to theory and practice of application of combatives - self-defense. Corse is focused on personal defense with using knowledge of cycle of conflict.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: None
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. Theoretical test - technical means of self-defense, timing of defense, ladder of use of force
    2. Technical test - overturning a lying opponent, abduction techniques
    3. Conditioning test - tacfit
    4. Exam - theoretical part (according to obligatory literature) - practical part (solving of model self-defence situations according to subject curriculum)
TEACHING_METHODS: Explication, demonstration, exercises, drills. Self-study - recommended literature - e-learning - individual exercises
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: At the end of the course student should be able to: - define self-defence and its place in the taxonomy of combatives - understand the difference between training and performance in combatives sports and self-defence - describe basic self-defence concepts - explain legal limits of self-defence - show basic self-defence techniques according to subject curriculum - understand and apply basic strategical, tactical and technical principles of self-defence - solve basic model self-defence situation
LITERATURE:

NAME: Methodology
TEACHERS: Sebera, M. - Bozděch, M.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, F, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
Topic - Search and Selection, Archive of Final Thesis at MU Brno and UK Prague.
    Citation standard, creation of bibliographic records, citation managers.
    Structure and design of the project (research, problem, goal, research questions (hypotheses), methodology, studied subjects / objects, data source, data acquisition method, data analysis, study definition, study limits).
    Structure of theoretical, theoretical and empirical work. Methods and techniques, tools and variants of research.
    Methods of data collection (observation, methods, experiment, quaziexperiment).
    Data Processing Methods - Analysis, Synthesis, Review, Thinking and Logic Methods, Statistics.
    Basic statistical characteristics - mean, median, standard deviation, frequency, basic graphs - histogram, box graph.
    Statistics sw.
    Statistical and Effect Size
    Interpretation of results.
    Assessment and defense of the bachelor thesis.
OBJECTIVES: The aim is to prepare the student for the necessary steps in the bachelor thesis. Adoption of principles of professional work, access to the world of professional literature, methods of selecting topics and methods of professional work, work with literature and information sources. They will be acquainted with citation methods and bibliographic references. Basic research strategies, research plans and methods of data collection and analysis.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
- written test: 40 questions. There is one point for a correct answer, -0.25 points for an incorrect answer and 0 points for an unanswered question. The threshold to be met is 32 points (80%). It will be possible to get 10 bonus points at the lectures (max. 1 point per lecture in the form of a quiz - the KvIS tool), which will be added to the result of the written test. Rating E: 32 points; D: 33-34 p.; C: 35-36 p.; B: 37-38 p.; A: 39-40+ p.
    - bachelor's thesis project on the chosen topic assessed as passed/failed
TEACHER_INFO: Vybraná témata mohou být prezentována a vyučována hybridní formou.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
At the end of the course students should be able to:
    to define science branch Kinantropologie
    to make a bachelor's thesis topic
    to create a structure of thesis
    to find relevant resources and create a research
    to determine the research problem, goals, questions and hypotheses
    to describe the research plan (strategies, methods of data acquisition and processing)
    specify the sample file and the method of selection
    specify the research file and the method of selection
    to analyze and interpret the results
LITERATURE:
SEBERA, Martin a Renata KLÁROVÁ. Aplikovaná matematická statistika. Online. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2014, s. nestránkováno, 51 s. ISBN 978-80-210-7427-9. URL info

NAME: English
TEACHERS: Dlabolová, D. - Prucklová, R. - Vyorálková, J. - Bilková, S. - Šimek, R.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: 1st Week: Determinants of Physical Activity among the General Public - listening, note taking, presenting 2nd Week: Winter Sports I/ Articles and Determiners I, Murphy Unit70 3rd Week: Winter Sports II/ Articles and Determiners II 4th Week: Stadium Team Games/ Academic Writing – Letter 5th Week: Court Games I/ Conditional I Murphy U25 6th Week: Court Games II/ Conditional II Murphy U38 7th Week: Water Sports/ Adjectives, adverbs 8th Week: Athletics/ Passive Voice 9th Week: Gymnastics/ Relative Clauses 10th Week: Adventure Sports, Combat Sports/ Listening to a Lecture 11th Week: Fitness / Human Anatomy/ Collocations and Phrasal Verbs Sports Idioms 12th Week: Academic reading/ understanding the main idea of a text, organizing key information, writing a summary 13th Week: Revision lesson
OBJECTIVES: The course is designed to provide students with knowledge of various sports disciplines and related topics while developing their reading comprehension, and oral and written skills in English. By the end of the course, students are expected to have reached the B2 level of the CEFR.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: B1 level of English according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages is expected
ASSESMENT_METHODS: The course is taught in the form of seminars. Students will find topics for each week in the interactive syllabus section ("interaktivní osnova"), and prepare them for the following classes. The items: U3 etc. indicate the number of a unit in the above grammar textbook. The course is completed by an exam. 1 unexcused missed attendance is accepted.
TEACHING_METHODS: Language seminar: speaking,reading, listening, writing, presenting
TEACHER_INFO: The exam at the end of the course comprises testing all language skills: speaking, reading, writing, listening. The topics for the oral part can be found in the materials to study.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Graduates of this course will acquire command of professional terminology in sport science, health and various sport disciplines. By the end of the course students students will be able to use professionally relevant grammatical phenomena. The improvement of reproductive communication skills (proper pronunciation, correct spelling, apt use of stylistic registers in written communication and acquisition of basic lexical knowledge) will be emphasized and their eventual mastery expected.
LITERATURE: MURPHY, Raymond. English grammar in use : a self-study reference and practice book for intermediate learners of English : with answers. Fourth edition. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2012, x, 380. ISBN 9780521189064. info

NAME: Pedagogy
TEACHERS: Jůva, V. - Jůva, V. - Možná, T. - Sliacky, J. - Szemla, F.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: 1. The concept of education. Education and socialization; value orientation of education; the relationship of education, genetics and the environment. 2. Basic features of contemporary education. Features of democratic education. Formal, non-formal and informal learning. 3. The concept of pedagogy. The origins of pedagogy (Aristotle, Quintilianus, Comenius, Herbart). Contemporary concepts of pedagogy. Relation of pedagogy to other disciplines. Relation of pedagogy, kinanthropology and sports sciences. 4. Structure of pedagogy (system of pedagogical disciplines) and its importance in society. 5. Elements of the educational process (objectives, participants, conditions and resources). 6. Selected historical education models (Comenius, Locke, Rousseau, Dewey). 7. Educational goals - current goals of contemporary education. Preparing an individual for social roles (education for the life of H. Spencer, requirements of postmodern society). 8. Education as a development of basic qualities of personality. Education and training. Content of education - education and culture. 9. Teacher (educator, teacher, coach, teacher assistant, ...) - his education, competencies and personality characteristics. 10. Education of an individual (child, pupil, student, client, athlete, ...). Selected research of contemporary youth. 11. Forms of education (school, out-of-school, family). Education and leisure. 12. The system of pedagogical principles and their application.
OBJECTIVES: Encompassment of basic pedagogical categories, concepts and theories, with an emphasis on creating the basics of pedagogical competencies.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Basics of Social Sciences.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Active participation, preparation and presentation of the individual home work, written test, oral exam
TEACHING_METHODS: Lecture, group discussion, individual home work
LITERATURE:
PRŮCHA, Jan. Přehled pedagogiky : úvod do studia oboru. 4., aktualizované vydání. Praha: Portál, 2015, 270 stran. ISBN 9788026208723. info

NAME: Basic and Rhythmic Gymnastics
TEACHERS: Gregorovič, G. - Skotáková, A. - Vaculíková, P.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_gym2 )
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
Terminology of physical exercises
    Warm ups (main principles and individual parts of warm up)
    - joint-mobilisation exercises
    - dynamic warm up
    - coordination exercises
    - toning exercises
    Stretching (different kinds of stretching and its use in practise)
    Strengthen exercises:
    - abdominal muscles
    - back muscles
    - arms and trunk muscles
    - gluteus and legs
    - complex strengthening exercises For all exercises the correct terminology of physical exercises will be applied, the function of muscle groups and the correct execution of the individual exercises explained and the problems of breathing clarified.
    Music-movement theory – what is rhythm, rhythmic ability, why is it important to develop coordination skills, including rhythmic. What is counting time and metric impulse, or master beat
    - Use of music in movement activities – music as a basis or delimitation of movement content, movement exercises according to the presented rhythm, overlap into socio-emotional development and diagnostics of the climate in the group
    - Development of coordination skills – principles and creation in pairs, trios, basics of learning movement combinations and practice of giving feedback
    - Practice of individual dance steps and step connections – approach, transformation, polka, hop step, arm movements, scissors, long jump, stag jump, cadet, waltz step. Demonstration of various methodological procedures for teaching coordination-demanding exercises and combinations
    - Rhythmic games and exercises for different age groups
    - Basic dances – waltz, polka, jive, cha-cha, street dance
    - Basic and more advanced jumps and exercises with a skipping rope – creating a group combination
OBJECTIVES:
The aims of the subject (part Basic gymnastics) are following:
    - Familiarization with methodological and didactic procedures during warm up (without/with accompaniment of music)
    - Application of joint-mobilisation exercises
    - Interconnection of theoretical and practical knowledge from the area of the stretching and the strengthening and their use in individual parts of the exercise unit
    - Familiarization with the Czech gymnastics terminology of physical exercises and graphic recording of the motion
    The aims of the subject (part Rytmic gymnastics) are following:
    - master the basics of music and movement theory and be able to apply them in practice (rhythm, tempo, beat, counting time, metric impulse)
    - learn the meaning of using music in movement activities and sports (development of coordination, social-emotional development, building cooperation of participants in movement activities)
    - learn the importance of developing coordination and movement memory
    - learn to perceive the quality of movement and learn to give feedback to others
    - master basic dance elements, steps, jumps and turns and learn to create short movement sequences
    - become theoretically and practically acquainted with individual types of dances (folk, country, street dance)
    - learn to apply musical accompaniment to teaching or training units in individual sports and movement activities
    - master the basic and more advanced technique of jumping rope exercises by musical accompaniment
    - learn to compose simple movement combinations for musical accompaniment
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
- active participation in classes (permitted absence - 4 absences regardless of whether they are excused or unexcused, in case of a larger number of absences, compensation is allowed only after prior agreement with the teacher of the seminar group).
    Part Basic gymnastics - written and graphic preparation of warm-up (12-15 exercises), main part or final stretching processed according to the instructions presented in the lessons
    - microteaching - warm-up, main part, or final stretching during the semester
    video - warm-up, main part, or final stretching
    - peer assessment of chosen videos (6x)
    - feedback

    - practical requirements:
    pull-ups - men 10 reps, women 5 reps
    push-ups - men 20 reps, women 10 reps
    hanging leg raises - men 5 reps, women 3 reps
    reverse plank - lifting right/left leg - holding the position for 10s each leg  
    standing forward bend, fingers on the mat - holding the position for 10 s  
    sitting with legs apart, arms raised - holding the position for 10 s  
    - active participation in classes, fulfillment of partial tasks on time and in high quality
    part Rhythmic gymnastics
    Feedback during the semester
    - active participation in classes (permitted absence - 2 hours)
    - complete two partial tasks during the semester:
    Create a part of a dynamic warm-up to musical accompaniment
    Create a combination with a skipping rope to musical accompaniment
    During the exam period, choose from two options
    - movement task with your own musical accompaniment, any style, mandatory elements in IO
    - Preparatory exercise for at least 3 people - preparatory exercise for a certain sport (organize, motivate, teach participants)
    Details about credit requirements can be found in the interactive curriculum.
TEACHING_METHODS: Practical exercises supplemented with theoretical explanations. Pair work, group work Didactic games Simulation techniques
TEACHER_INFO:
https://is.muni.cz/elportal/?id=936375
    http://www.fsps.muni.cz/frvs/2012/zakladni-gymnastika/
    https://is.muni.cz/do/1451/e-learning/kineziologie/elportal/pages/druhy_svalove_kontrakce.html

    V případě opakovaného zápisu předmětu je student povinen předmět opakovat v plném rozsahu dle sylabu předmětu pro daný semestr, pokud se s vyučujícími písemně nedomluví na začátku semestru jinak.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
At the end of the course students should be able to:
    - know the list of stretch and strengthen exercises for different muscles of the body
    - know the correct execution of these exercises
    - form and lead the warm up (without/with accompaniment of music), circuit training, final stretching
    - know the correct Czech terminology of physical exercises
    - able to identify individual counting times in musical accompaniment, recognize metric impulse or master beat
    - be able to choose adequate musical accompaniment for the presented movement exercises
    - be able to perform basic dance elements, steps, jumps, turns and use them for preparatory or other exercises
    - be able to create movement combinations to the given musical accompaniment
    - be able to perform basic and more advanced jumps over a rope by the music

    - to know other uses of musical accompaniment in movement activities (emotional and social development, use in experiential activities, development of cooperation)

NAME: Anatomy
TEACHERS: Gimunová, M. - Juříková, J. - Gimunová, M. - Juříková, J.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Introduction to Anatomy - cell, tissue, terminology. Bones - structure types. Axial skeleton (skull, spine, pelvis), upper limb skeleton, skeleton legs. Connection of bones, joints - Components, types, movements, individual joints. Muscles - structure, component types. Muscles of the head, neck, back and abdomen (including motor function). The muscles of the upper extremity, lower extremity muscles (including motor function).
OBJECTIVES: The aim of this course is to obtain a comprehensive view on human body and morphological factors influencing its movement. For this, it is necessary to understand the basics of individual organs and organ systems structures, especially the anatomy of the skeletal system, joints and muscles.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Successfully completed oral exam.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Successful completion of the subject Anatomy will allow you to understand the basic structure and structure of the human body - the necessary attributes for perceiving the body as a whole.
    The acquired knowledge from the area of functional anatomy will then be applied in follow-up professional subjects.
    The FSpS graduate must have an anatomical idea of the human body in order to understand the possibilities of adaptation, training, exercise and regeneration of the organism in childhood, adulthood and old age.
    Completing the course Anatomy is a necessary prerequisite for the enrollment of courses followed in further study at the FSpS.
LITERATURE:

NAME: Physiology
TEACHERS: Bernaciková, M. - Vomela, J. - Čechovská, I. - Juříková, J. - Kapounková, K. - Sitek, O. - Strašilová, K.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
Syllabus and Concept of Selective Lectures:
    1) Introduction to physiology:
    - basic cell functions
    - what is homeostasis
    2) + 3) Principles of neurohumoral control and regulation of functions of the human organism
    4) Fundamentals of metabolism and physiology of body fluids; Secretion
    5) Function of cardiovascular apparatus; Blood composition
    6) Breathing, gas transmission, acid-base balance
    7) Functions of the digestive system
    8) Functions of the locomotive apparatus
    9) Immune system
    10) Adaptation of the organism (stress, stress, illness, age and gender factors, external environment, etc.)
    11) Biorhythms
    12) + 13) Free additional topics

    Syllabus of exercises:
    1) Introduction to Exercise Physiology, assignment of semestral projects
    2) Body structure and composition (anthropological examination)
    3) Motion system I (muscle fiber diagnostics, genetic assumptions)
    4) Motion system II (types of muscle contraction, dynamometry)
    5) Metabolism (Measurement of Resting Metabolism, Indirect Energometry)
    6) Body fluids (La, GLY measurements)
    7) Cardiovascular system (HR measurement, BP measurement, Q and Qs calculation)
    8) Cardiovascular system (ECG, HR variability)
    9) Respiratory system (BR, TV, VE - spirometry)
    10) Control system (nervous system, endocrine system)
    11) Excretory system (urine examination)
    12) Senses (visual examination, vestibular system)
    13) a) Protocols checking + presentation of semestral projects b) Credit test
OBJECTIVES:
Teaching Physics is not an end in itself. The subject is thematically oriented so that the basic information about the function of the human body and its organs is presented to the students at the lectures (selected key themes), then discussed in Seminars and practically applied in the Exercise, where the student will actively participate in the realization of specific tasks , exercises and tests and program essays. Part of the Exercise will be the separate elaboration of worksheets.
    The course is designed so that the student can understand the basic functions of the human body as a whole, as well as the function of the organs, and understand the mutual interaction of the human organism and the external environment for the maintenance of homeostasis.
    Similarly, it will be mentioned how the function of the human organism (and the function of its individual organs) will affect the physical burden, illness, stress,
    Students are familiar with differences in the functions of the human body in childhood, adulthood and old age.
    Knowledge gained through the study of Physiology will allow students to understand the concepts and processes in the human organism that the student encounters in the next follow-up studies at FSpS. Understand the changes that occur in our organism in individual types of sport, it will know how to focus and individualize the training and regeneration load. The completion of the subject of Physiology is a necessary prerequisite for enrollment of subjects related to further study at FSpS.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS:
The basic prerequisite for the beginning of Physiology studies are:
    - Regular enrollment of the subject
    - knowledge of the student at the level of biology teaching at high school
    - knowledge gained through study in the subject ANATOMY (bp4008).
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Subject physiology is normally completed by credit and examination.
    The basic prerequisite for granting the credit is:
    a) fulfillment of the duties prescribed within the subject (successful completion of Exercises and Seminars, elaboration of worksheets and semestral project). Compliance with these obligations is necessary to complete the credit test.
    b) passing a credit test (50 questions - maximum possible number of points obtained = 50) at least 70%.
    Entry to the oral exam is conditional upon the award of the Credit.
    Participation in seminars and seminars is mandatory. A maximum of 2 absences are tolerated, topics missing and need to be explained.
TEACHING_METHODS:
A) Lectures of selected topics - as an introduction to study.
    B) Exercises and seminars include the theoretical and practical part of the lesson. Prerequisite for participation in the Exercise is the knowledge of basic information about the particular lesson.
    C) Self-study of recommended literature
    Teaching methods: presentation, discussion, practical measurements, group projects, essay processing, brainstorming. Testing knowledge.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Successful completion of the subject of Physiology will make it possible to understand the basic principles of homeostasis (ability to stabilize the internal environment of the organism), which are a necessary condition of the body as a whole, as well as its individual organs.
    Understand what is happening in the human organism, due to the burden, age, illness, stress,
    The knowledge gained will allow you to understand the basic functions of the human body as a whole (system) and the function of the organs.
    Graduates of the FSpS have to know the possibilities of adapting, training, loading and regeneration of the organism in childhood, adulthood and old age.
    The knowledge gained in this subject will allow students to understand the concepts and processes in the human organism with which the FSpS student will meet in related subjects. Thanks to the knowledge of the body's function, it understands the changes that occur in our body in individual types of sport and will know how to focus and individualize the training and regeneration load.
    The completion of the subject of Physiology is a necessary prerequisite for enrollment of subjects related to further study at FSpS.
LITERATURE:
BERNACIKOVÁ,M, Kapounková K., Novotný J., Vomela J., Vomelová N. Fyziologie člověka pro studenty bakalářských oborů Tělesné výchovy. FSpS MU, 2014. ISBN: 978-80-210-7697-6

SYLLABUS:
Blocks:

    2. shooting (lay-up, set shot),
    3. passing and catching the ball,
    4. rebounding, moving without the ball,
    5. guarding the player with/without the ball, individual defensive skills against two opponents,

OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to create the right physical habits in the teaching of individual basketball skills and basic game combinations. Students will also be introduced to basic basketball rules.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
80% attendance
    Credit is based on two parts: practical test of individual basketball skills and basic game combinations and an e-learning test of basketball rules.

    2. "give and go" situation, drive and finishing with shot,
    3. game situation 3-on-3, full court.

    E-learning test from basketball rules: 30 questions in given time.

    The overal grade will be based on score students gain from the test. Students must pass each part of the test to earn the credits. Failing one part of the test means failing the test as a whole.

LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
When successfully completing the course, the student will be able to:

    - use individual offensive skills,
    - use individual defensive skills,
    - use the basic "give and go" combination of play and understand the nature of fast break situation,
    - characterize basketball and master basketball rules.

NAME: Anthropomotricity and Biomechanics
TEACHERS: Kalichová, M. - Zvonař, M. - Kalichová, M. - Vespalec, T. - Vodička, T.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Definition of biomechanics, importace, history. Physical base of biomechanics: line coordinates, scalares, vectores, units. Kinematics: mass point, distance, velocity, acceleration, straight motion, accelerated motion, cirgular motion, motions in field of gravity of Earth, describing motion with graphs. Dynamics: force, Newton's Laws, effects of force, deformations, Hook's Law, momentum and its conservation, impulse, centripetal force, inertial force, D'Alambert's Principle. Mechanics of rigid body: moment of force, principle of moments, centre of gravity, equilibrium positions, statics, frictional force, air resistance force, inclined plane, lever systems. Mechanical energy, work, power, conservation of energy. Mechanics of liquid and gas: pressure, Pascal's law, Hydrostatic pressure, law of Archimedes, equation of kontinuity, Bernoulli's equation, liquid flow around an obstacle. Biological base of biomechanics: body segments, biomechanisme, weight and centre of gravity of segments, centre of gravity of humen body, angular momentum of segments, mechanics properties of skeletal system, mechanics of joint connections, mechanics of muscle, mechanics load and deformation of tissues. Measurement and experiment in biomechanics. Biomechanics applications. Description of abilities and skills. Diagnostic methods of skill levels - motor tests The motor learning process. Laterality Ontoogenesis of motorics
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the subject is to explain the mechanical structure and mechanical behavior of the movement apparatus of the human in motion, especially the sport, and in this approach the research methods, based on which the human body is analyzed. Further, the aim of the subject is to acquaint students with the basic prerequisites for physical activity (skills and abilities), with the diagnostic methods of these assumptions and with the main manifestations during ontogenesis.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: seminar work; presentation of biomechanical paper; written test; oral exam
TEACHING_METHODS: theoretical presentations; applications on exercises; biomechanical expert studies presentation; application of motor tests
TEACHER_INFO: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/biomechanika
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: At the end of the course students will be able to: explain basic mechanical laws and principles; ontogenesis rules and the motor learning process and to synthesize this knowledge in the future with previously acquired knowledge of selected biological subsystems; to apply the basic knowledge of this synergetic scientific discipline to the human system of motion and sport movement; from a kinematic and dynamic perspective to analyze the nature of the selected sport movement; to propose appropriate biomechanical measurements to solve the problem, to diagnose the level of physical abilities
LITERATURE:

NAME: Track and Field 1
TEACHERS: Adamík, R. - Hlavoňová, Z.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_atlet )
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
1. lesson - warm-up, cool down
    2. lesson - running drills
    3. lesson - starts, rhythmizing excersises
    4. lesson - technique of running
    5. lesson - hurdle drills, rhythmizing excersises
    6. lesson - training hurdle running (3-step, 4-step and 5-step rhytm)
    7. lesson - practise relay exchange (up-sweep and down-sweep)
    8. lesson - practise relay 4x 60m, 4 x 100 m, 4 x 400 m
    9. lesson - technique of throwing with a cricet ball and javelin
    10. lesson - kids athletics - technnique of running development, speed development, endurance and hurdle running
    11. lesson - preparation for fulfillment of the requirements
    12. lesson - rehearsal of track and field rules and technique of mentioned events
OBJECTIVES:
The aim of subject Track and Field I is to provide theoretical knowledge and training practical skills:
    the correct technique of drive and stride phase of running,
    starts,
    the correct elementary, running and hurdle drills,
    hurdle running (3-step, 4-step and 5-step rhythm),
    relay exchange (up-sweep and down-sweep),
    correct technique of throwing with a cricet ball and javelin
    basic rules of Track and Field events and principles of safety in the lessons.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Credits are obtained after fulfillment of the requirements:
    active attendence in lessons (1 missed lesson is allowed),
    ability to perform 3 randomly selected running and hurdle drill excercise,
    . running over 5 hurdle (3-step,4-step and ř-step rhytm and school-boys height),
    performing proper technique of drive (30 m) and stride (100 m) running phase,
    the correct technique of throwing with a ball
    pass written final test
TEACHING_METHODS: Practical exercises at the athletic stadium. Self study e-learning form.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After successful completion of the subject Track and Field I student will be able to:
    apply the correct technique of drive and stride phase, starts,
    demonstrate the correct technique of elementary, running and hurdle drills,
    use the correct technique of hurdle running (3-step and 4-step rhytm),
    practise relay exchange (up-sweep and down-sweep),
    manage correct technique of throwing with a cricet ball and javelin,
    analyze (and critically evaluate) the most frequently occurring errors in technique perform the above mentioned events,
    demonstrate knowledge of basic rules mentioned Track and Field events and safety on lessons.
LITERATURE:

NAME: Skating

SYLLABUS:
Basic skating training according to the methodical series: Teaching is primarily focused on mastering the technique: forward, stop, reverse, ride in turns, forward and reverse, forward and outward swings, turns, jumps and ice games.
    Part of the lesson is to master warm-up, relaxation and stretching exercises, and safety precautions in skating lessons. Taking advantage of the skating tire as a prevention of injuries (injuries).
    Extended didactic skating series - circles forward and inward Part of the lesson is the use of e-learning materials for the skilful basics didactics.
OBJECTIVES: At the end of this course the student will be able to: Demonstrated skills bases skating
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Active participation in lessons, skill tests.
TEACHER_INFO: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/zaklady-brusleni-ledniho-hokeje-a-krasobrusleni/
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After solving the subject, the student will be able to: -option theoretically the basic methodical skating series; -poping an extended methodical skating series; Practically handle individual elements of skating basics; -analyze shortcomings in practical demonstrations and propose a solution; -Take principles of warm-up, relaxation and stretching as a prevention of injuries.

NAME: Culture of Speech and Academic Writing
TEACHERS: Hurych, E. - Palka, J.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Culture of performance – written, oral, presented. Verbal and nonverbal performance, body speech. Cultural versus non-cultural. The fields of human communication and the specificities. Communication competence, communication in stress situations, communication in groups. Scientific works, scientific methodology. Sources and the process of searching and selecting information. The formal structure of the scientific texts, their characteristics, how to write introduction. Kinds of scientific texts and the specific parts. How to work with information, plagiary, ethics of research. Citations, bibliography, supplements, citation norms. Presentation of the results. Creative writing, processes (brainstorming, mind maps etc.).
OBJECTIVES: The main aim of the course is to develop the students´abilities in the next main fields: Cultura of performance. Communication skills. Writing skills - scientific work, scientific methodology. Formal demands of the scientific text and abilitiy to work with sources. Presentation of the results in both the written and oral forms.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: The minimal presence in practical lessons = 80%; 1 active presentation during the term; the autoevaluation essay based on the presentation; written test (min. 15 points from 20).
TEACHING_METHODS: Lectures, practical exercises (individual and group projects), discussion, independent work
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: The student will be able to define basic demands on culture of performance in th eoral and written form and he/she will be also able to identify basic principles of culture within a model form of the presented outputs. In written form he/seh can use all the knowledge in the topographic, grammar and stylistic demonstrations. He/she will prove ability to work with written sources - their selection, meaningful implementation and using citation norms.
LITERATURE:
ŠANDEROVÁ, Jadwiga. Jak číst a psát odborný text ve společenských vědách. Praha: Sociologické nakladatelství, 2009, 209 s. Studijní texty, 34. svazek. ISBN 978-80-86429-40-3. info

NAME: Preparation for Practice
TEACHERS: Roček, M. - Roček, M. - Čechová, O.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
1. Acquaintance with the subject and its organization system
    2. On the basis of theoretical knowledge, the student will be able to implement the subsequent practice b4030 in selected organizations.
    3. The student will be able to analyse and diagnose movement units and individual activities of the trainee teacher.
    4. The student will be able to actively participate in the analysis of all lessons with the teacher.
    5. Based on the topics covered, the student will be able to prepare their own movement units.
    6. He gains experience in conducting various types of motion units.
OBJECTIVES: Practice is an important and inseparable part of the undergraduate training of future instructors, trainers and educators. The aim of this training is to gain a balanced knowledge of pedagogy, psychology, general didactics as well as practical training. It is therefore necessary during the course of study to give students the opportunity to acquaint themselves with the various work activities of physical education specialists and to enable the training of pedagogical activities in the main areas of their possible application. Students will deepen their knowledge in both the theoretical and practical problems of organizing movement leisure activities and will better evaluate the pedagogical educational activities.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 1/ active participation in teaching 2/ preparation of all assigned tasks and investigations, maintenance of pedagogical documentation (hospital records, analyses) 3/ presentation on a chosen or assigned topic 4/ selection of follow-up practice
TEACHING_METHODS: theoretical and practical preparation in the form of lectures and seminars, hospitalization in selected facilities, tasks for separate work.

NAME: Management Fundamentals in Sport
TEACHERS: Racek, O. - Sedláček, T. - Kadlec, J. - Kotas, J. - Kyselica, A. - Racek, O. - Vyroubal, M.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps ) && ( semestr ( 4 )|| semestr ( 5 ))
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
1. Meaning of management and basic terms
    2. Personality of the manager of his role and role
    3. Basic managerial skills and their use in practice
    4. Basic economic concepts - supply, demand, market
    5. Measuring economic performance, inflation, unemployment
    6. Banking and money
    7. Basic concepts of marketing
    8. Organization of sport in the Czech Republic
    9. Basics of business in sport
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to acquaint students with basic concepts in the field of management, marketing, economics and their possible applications in practice. Orient in the world of finance, the possibilities of doing business in sport and in organizing sports in the Czech Republic.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The course ends with a final test with a pass/fail result (the student must obtain a minimum of 60 points).
    The student will be admitted to the colloquium if he/she actively participates in the seminars, presents properly and submits the seminar work on time (i.e., obtains a minimum of 51 points in the seminars - all information on the seminar requirements is inserted in the course materials).
    If a student commits any disciplinary infraction, that action will be considered a failure to meet the requirements for completion of the course. The instructor will close the examination (credit) with a grade of "F" in the IS and the Dean will initiate disciplinary proceedings which may result in termination. Translated with DeepL.com (free version)
TEACHING_METHODS:
Teaching is conducted in the form of lectures and seminars.
    The content of the seminars will be the application of the acquired theoretical knowledge to the practical use (managerial skills), the other problems will be practiced by case studies, where the students are expected to discuss the given issue, based on the theoretical basis obtained at the lectures.
    The student will prepare and present a seminar paper.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
- Define and explain the basic concepts of management, marketing and economics
    - Apply managerial skills in specific situations
    - Understand the fundamentals of finance and apply this knowledge in various life situations
    - to know the organization of sport in the Czech Republic
    - gain basic knowledge in the field of business in sport
LITERATURE:
ZAMAZALOVÁ, Marcela. Marketing. Vyd. 2. Praha: C.H.Beck, 2010, xxiv, 499. ISBN 9788074001154. info
        SRPOVÁ, Jitka a Václav ŘEHOŘ. Základy podnikání : teoretické poznatky, příklady a zkušenosti českých podnikatelů. 1. vyd. Praha: Grada, 2010, 427 s. ISBN 9788024733395. URL info

        BĚLOHLÁVEK, František, Pavol KOŠŤAN a Oldřich ŠULEŘ. Management. 1. vyd. Olomouc: Rubico, 2001, 642 s. ISBN 8085839458. info

NAME: Movement and Health
TEACHERS: Vomela, J. - Bernaciková, M. - Mojžíš, M.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
1. Reciprocal positive and negative relations between health and exercise or sport activity
    2. Oxidative stress and rhabdomyolysis after endurance physical performance - causation, symptoms, consequences, prevention
    3. Helath problems of exercise and sport in extreme climatic conditions (hypohydratation, hyponatremia, hyperthermia, hypothermia, altitude illness, dive injuries and decompression illness)
    4. Sudden cardiac death during sport aktivity - - causation, prevention
    5. Preventive medical examens - purpose, content, conclusions
    6. Overuse injuries of locomotive apparatus - causation, prevention, rules of treatment
    7. Orthesis, classic taping and kinesiotaping - purposes, rules of application
    8. Management of exercise and sport training and competion with minimalization of health problems
    9. Health risks of doping in sport
    10. Specific prevention of health risk of women, children and seniors during exercise and sport activity.
    11. Prevention of health risks during endurance running, cycling, swimming.
    12. Helath injuries after aggressive behaviour in sport - footbal, ice hockey, box.
    13. Exercise and sport activities of cardiac patients and peoples with blood hypertension - positive effects, and prevention of problems.
    14. Exercise and sport of patients with asthma bronchiale.
    15. Exercise and sport of patients with diabetes mellitus.
    16. Exercise and sport of patients with migraine.
OBJECTIVES:
At the end of the course students should be able to
    - consider relationship between health and physical activity
    - pursue an effective prevention, to deal with health problems during exercises or sport training etc.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Knowledge of human anatomy and physiology is supposed.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Colloquium
TEACHER_INFO: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/sportovni-medicina/
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
At the end of the course students should be able to:
    1. list and explain reciprocal relations between health and exercise or sport activity
    2. discuss to causation, prevention and consequences of injuries and failures of physiological organs and systems (locomotive, cardiovascular, respirátory, endocrine, metabolic, immune)
    3. analyze chosen exercise or sport aktivity (e.g. endurance and strength training, running, cycling and swimming, common ball games) and identify its health risks
    4. plan of exercise or sport activity with minimal health risks
LITERATURE:
Novotný J, Sebera M, Hrazdira L, Novotná M. Kapitoly sportovní medicíny, Paido/FSpS MU 2003, www.fsps.muni.cz/ucebniceNovotny
        Kučera M. a kol. Dítě, sport a zdraví. Galén, Praha 2011
        MÁČEK, Miloš a Jiří RADVANSKÝ. Fyziologie a klinické aspekty pohybové aktivity. První vydání. Praha: Galén, 2011, xvi, 245. ISBN 9788072626953. info
        O´Connor et al. ACSM´S Sports Medicine. A Comprehensive Review. Wolters Cluwer, Philadelphia, Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, 2013, 857 pp.

    12. preparation for fulfillment of the requirements, rehearsal of track and field rules and technique of mentioned events.
OBJECTIVES:
The aim of subject Track and Field 2 is provide theoretical knowledge and training practical skills:
    the correct technique of long jump, high jump, shot put,
    basic rules of track and field events, and principles of safety in the lessons.
    flexibility, mobility, strength training, plyometrics excersises
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Credits are obtained after fulfillment of the requirements:
    complete combine events on the required level,
    active attendence in lessons (1 missed lesson is allowed)
    written test (15 correct answers are needed pass the test)
    Practical fulfillment will be evaluated according to valid decathlon and hepthatlon scoring tables.
TEACHING_METHODS: Practical exercises at the athletic stadium. Self study e-learning form.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After successful completion of the subject Track and Field 2 student will be able to:
    apply the correct technique of long jump, high jump, and shot put,
    analyze (and critically evaluate) the most frequently occurring errors in technique perform the above mentioned events,
    complete combine events on the required level,
    demonstrate knowledge of basic rules mentioned Track and Field events, and safety on lessons.
