NAME: Preparatory Combatives
TEACHERS: Janoušková, S. - Novák, J. - Reguli Čihounková, J. - Válek, J. - Vít, M. - Kubíčková, V.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_upoly )
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Introduction to preparatory combatives - characteristic of combatives - taxonomy of combatives - function of combatives in school physical education Basic combative techniques 1. contact establishment 2. postures, transitions between postures 3. transfers 4. arm movements 5. leg movements 6. lifting, carrying and dropping of a live load (partner) turning the body, changing position 7. falling techniques (principles, psychology, tactics and bimechanics) Basic combatives 1. centrifugal (pulls) 2. centripetal (pushes) 3. opposition (resistance Combative games
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to acquire the knowledge about taxonomy of combatives, structure and use of preparatory combatives as a mean of motor abilities development in physical education and sports.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Student - knows taxonomy of preparatory combatives and characterize each group of exercises - is well informed about history of combat sports
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 1. Theoretical test - will verify knowledge of taxonomy and biomechanics of combatives 2. Practical test a) 8 exercises of preparatory combatives for developing of different motor ability b) 6 basic falling techniques to all directions
TEACHING_METHODS: Explication, exercises, individual physical preparation, drills, individual tasks: literature and e-learning study. Task control: questions and tasks in the class, submission of videos, mutual evaluation, final examination (theoretical test, practical test, seminar work).

NAME: Football
TEACHERS: Bokůvka, D.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_fotbal )
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Movement on the pitch Passing and receiving the ball Dribbling and one-on-one situations Goalkeeping Shooting Heading Attacking combinations Defensive combinations Gameplay Technical skills' test
OBJECTIVES: Students will be familiarized with the game's basic rules, terminology, and theoretical knowledge about the game and its contents. The practical part of the subject focuses on the practice of attacking and defensive football skills and the practical interpretation of theoretical knowledge. This knowledge and skills will be used in students' further study and practice. Basic structure, content and principles of distinctive parts of the teaching unit will be presented in this subject. Students will practice delivering the preparatory part of the unit, discussing both methodological and didactic procedures.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: The student is healthy and can perform physical activity to the full extent.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Football knowledge and skill tests, active participation in exercises (80 % seminar attendance). Gaming skills will be tested during an exercise where the student receives the ball, dribbles and then shoots the ball on the goal within a given time limit. The final written test consists of 20 questions. If a student makes more than four mistakes, he or she must sit a re-test. The final evaluation consists of partial assessments of the practical skill test and a written test on football rules and theory. The assessment also includes handing in a warm-up plan and evaluation of another student's work via the Peer Assessment app. This subject assumes individual study of the rules, as well as individual skills training.
TEACHING_METHODS: Practical exercises; Self-study tasks: the study of football theory, Improving football skills. Task control: technical skills test
TEACHER_INFO:
http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/zaklady-fotbalu/
    Výuka tohoto předmětu probíhá na hřišti s umělým povrchem TJ Tatran Bohunice po dobu 6 týdnů . Nejvhodnější obuví do této výuky jsou turfy (kopačky s gumovými kolíčky), kopačky nebo tenisky s hrubou podrážkou. Jako podpůrný informační a organizační materiál slouží interaktivní osnova předmětu.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: At the end of this seminar, students will be able to explain the basic terminology and basic rules of the game and will be able to prepare and design the teaching unit. Students will be able to describe and explain the basic systematics of game performance in football, understand the rules of football, and be able to demonstrate selected individual gameplay activities and a sequence of individual gameplay activities in practice.

NAME: Didactic

SYLLABUS:
General didactic as a basis for teaching. Aims and issues of general didactic.
    Components of the educational process (aims, actors, conditions, methods).
    Teaching methods (with respect to age-related differences).
    Alternative and innovative methods.
    Teaching methods regarding special educational needs.
    Modes of classroom organization and lesson phases.
    Teaching and learning strategies.
    Curriculum. Content transformation.
    Classroom management (with respect to age-related differences: pre-primary, primary, secondary, adult education).
    Pedagogical diagnostic.
    Pedagogical communication.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is introduce relevant didactic categories and theoretical knowledge with respect to age-related differences of pupils and domains, in which will students work. Another aim is to enhance pedagogical thinking a pedagogical competencies.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Active participation, submitting a written lesson preparation, realisation and presentation of the individual homework, written test, oral exam.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After finishing the course, the student is able to explain key concepts of didactic, to analyze lesson with respect to educational needs of pupils, to choose appropriate teaching methods, to use diagnostic methods with respect to needs of students or groups, to apply principles of pedagogical communication in instruction.

NAME: Physical Activity for People with Diseases and Disabilities
TEACHERS: Grmela, R. - Kapounková, K. - Struhár, I. - Grmela, R. - Šimonová, M.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Physical education for deseas and disorders, aim, means, compensatory procedure • Functional desorders of locomotor apparatus (diagnostics and corrective procedure) • Several kind of desorders of locomotor apparatus and corrective procedure • Kinesiological analyse of motion and suitable compensatory exercises • Diseases of pulmonary apparatus and compensatory exercises • Obesity nad compensatory exercises • Diabetes mellitus type I, II and compensatory exercises • Diseases of Cardiovascular apparatus and compensatory exercises • Gynecological diseses nad compensatory exercises • Neuropsychological diseases and compensatory exercises • Diseases of sense and compensatory exercises • Ontology, specialities and pathogeny • Elderly available physical activities
OBJECTIVES: The subject deal with prescription of physic activity in disabled people. During study of this subject student will be informed about possibilities of diagnostics of locomotive apparatus, compensatory means, structure and content of exercise unite. Student will also develop procedures in choosing of proper physic activity in disorder of locomotive apparatus, respiratory system, cardiovascular system, obesity, diabetes mellitus, gynecologic disorder, neuropsychic disorder, disorder of sense, elderly and so on.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Admission requirements for the exam: - participation in seminars (1 absences are allowed) - completed practical methodical output - submitted investigation protocol marked by the teacher as fulfilled - credit test - success rate 70%, test content: theoretical and practical knowledge from lectures, seminars and study materials Final oral exam: - discussion of the investigation protocol - verification of knowledge from lectures and seminars
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Upon completion of this course the student will be able to: Carry out the orientative testing of the movement system for   weakened individuals (common to all disciplines). Propose an adequate balancing process for individual health impairments (common to all disciplines). Build an exercise unit for individual weaknesses in terms of developing the necessary indicators

NAME: Theory of Sports Training
TEACHERS: Hrubý, M. - Langer, F. - Hrubý, M. - Langer, F. - Nykodým, J.
FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, F, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS: Theory of Sport Training – basic principles Definition of sport Goals, tasks and outcomes of sport training Classification of sport performance Factorial structure of performance in sport Sports training tasks (strength&conditioning, technical, tactical and psychological preparation) Strength&Conditioning – definition, structure and methodology Technical preparation – motor learning and skill development Tactical preparation Psychological preparation Teaching methods Types of training units Short-term planning and programming
OBJECTIVES: During this subject students will synthesize theoretical knowledge of human anatomy, physiology, anthropomotorics, biomechanics and social studies. Students will apply these knowledge in the issue of adaptation of human organism to different types of sport training. Main objective is to help student understand basic principles and approaches of skill development of which lead to improvement of sport form and performance. Some special chapters will be also discused, for example diagnostics in sport, programming and planning of training process, classification of skills and many others. Students are in small groups, where they discuss and present their own work on related topics.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Written test using PC (close answers), condition to successfully pass the exam is 80% of the total score result for a particular test, active participation at the seminars,elaboration of a seminar paper on selected topic, and its PowerPoint presentation
TEACHER_INFO: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/teorie-sportovniho-treninku-1/
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: By the end of the subject students will be able to define, explain and correctly use basic terms such as sports training, performance, shape, form and to classify sports performance. They will be also able to define objectives, tasks and outcomes of sport training, explain process of adaptation and create training plan using appropriate stimulus (specific, nonspecific). Students will be taught to apply these knowledge in different sport disciplines.

NAME: Sociology
TEACHERS: Svoboda, A. - Svoboda, A. - Svobodová, Z. - Kubíčková, V. - Sebera, M.

SYLLABUS: Origin and development of sociology Society Social groups Social mobility Socialization Sociál structure Social position and social role Culture Mass culture Media and society Sport and society Organization, institution, bureaucracy Social unevenness Socio pathological problems Organized crime, corruption Roman in the Czech context Religion Family Globalization
OBJECTIVES: Main objective and content of this lesson is to present a describe principal problems of contemporary society and discuss it in English. In such tas main sociologicl concepts and problems of siciety are discussed - society, socialization, social groups, globalization, mass media, family, social pathology, corruption,religion etc. Accent is focused on mutual relations of global dominant cultural backgrounds including phenomenon of sport as the growing agent os mass culture in sedentary postmodern society.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Main objective of this lesson is to understand principal problems of contemporary society.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Writtem test Participation in seminars - one unexcused absence is allowed Seminary students presentation
TEACHING_METHODS: Lessons on sociology, study of relevant literature Seminary: Topical problems of contemporary society
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Main and fundamental objective of this subject is deeper understanding of operation and tendencies of contemporary postmodern, sedentary consumerist society. Students are supported to understand existing forms of socialization, mutual relations of different global levels of culture, function of mass media, mutual relations of social and cultural majority and minorities, functioning sport phenomenon as growing agent of mass culture.

NAME: Floorball and Softball
TEACHERS: Ovesný, T. - Šiška, S. - Vencúrik, T.

FIELDS_OF_STUDY: RKH, OKT, BTVSv, MS, T, RVS, SEBS, BTVSh
SYLLABUS:
Floorball course blocks:
    1. Basic Game Skills:
    - posture and holding a stick,
    - spacing.
    2. Individual game activities:
    - dribble,
    - keeping the ball,
    - catching and passing,
    - moving without ball,
    - moving with a ball,
    - shooting,
    - steal the ball,
    - goalkeeper skills.
    3. Game combinations:
    - give and go,
    - back passes,
    - small-sided floorball.

    Softball course blocks:
    1. throwing and catching the ball,
    2. pitch and strike,
    3. base run and basic tactics of the game.
OBJECTIVES: Students will be acquainted with the basic rules of floorball and softball. Students will be practically familiarized with game skills and combinations in floorball and softball.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. 80% attendance,
    2. floorball and softball rules – e-learning test,
    3. practical demonstration of chosen individual skills from floorball and softball.
TEACHER_INFO:
http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/florbal-softbal/
    http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/sportovni-hry-2/softbal/?HighlightString=softbal http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/florbal-softbal/
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the floorball part of the course, the student will understand the basic rules of floorball and master the individual floorball skills and game combinations.

TEACHERS: Mojžíš, M. - Zvonař, M.

SYLLABUS:
1. Assessing the Situation
    2. Risks linked with giving of first aid
    3. External and Internal bleeding
    4. Uncosciousness. CPR Guidelines GL2021
    5. Recovery position
    6. Aspiration of Foreign Object
    7. Cold related emergencies
    8. Heat related emergencies
    9. Intoxication and chemical burns
    10. Musculoskeletal Injuries. Spinal injuries
    11. Shock developement
    12. Non-Accidental Cases
    13. First Aid differences at water environment
OBJECTIVES: The subject acquaints students with the prevention of accidental and non-traumatic emergencies, basic theories and practice of first aid, including resuscitation (basic life support). The subject respects the principles and procedures of first aid in accordance with the modern development of the field.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Attandance
    Practical exam - CPR, bleeding and positioning
    Theoretical oral exam
TEACHING_METHODS: Theoretical and practical lectures of First Aid and CPR
TEACHER_INFO: https://is.muni.cz/elportal/?id=1359748
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Student will be able to:
    -name risks linked with giving of first aid including water environment
    – name life-saving acts
    -distinguish unconsciousness with kept vital signs from necessity of starting of CPR
    - practice CPR of adult, child, infant and by state of near-drowning
    - change procedure of CPR, if there is possibility to use AED
    - stop life-threatening bleeding
    – find out from mechanism of accident severity of possible damage of organism and react adequately
    - treat typical musculoskeletal injuries – deduce probable type of non-accidental case from symptoms and react to the situation adequately
    -treat thermal injuries and cold exposures
    - remove aspirated foreign object with proper technique depending on age of casualty
    -discuss about possibilities of prevention due to rise of accidental or non-accidental case at school, swimming pools or in common life

NAME: Exercise Physiology
TEACHERS: Kapounková, K. - Pospíšil, Z. - Vomela, J. - Bernaciková, M. - Grün, V. - Řehoř, A.
SYLLABUS:
Syllabus of lectures:
    - Characteristics of sport disciplines (type of load, duration of performance, load intensity). Sports Performance Factors.
    - Physiological principles of training.
    - Effect of genetics on performance. determinants of sport performance.
    - Stress response (control systems). Disturbance of homeostasis. Acidobasic equilibrium - stress acidosis. Response of the organism to different types of body load.
    - Metabolic performance characteristics (metabolic cover, energy sources, energy supply).
    - Functional Performance Characteristics (HR, VO2, LA, ..).
    - Characteristics of the athlete (load test to maximum: HR max, VO2 max, Wingate test: P max, AC, fatigue index, somatic characteristics).
    - Adaptation process. Regulation of adaptation processes. Adaptation mechanisms.
    - Specific adaptations of the organism to the burden (speed, force, endurance, force endurance, speed-force, coordinating aesthetic, combat, sports games).
    - Physiological differences during stress response and adaptation in relation to ontogenesis.
    - Influence of the environment on performance (cold, heat, pressure). Acclimatization.
    - Desecration process. Detrain.
    - Specifics of female response (menstrual cycle, pregnancy, childbirth, puerperium).

    Syllabus of exercises:
    - Introduction to exercise Physiology of the load, characteristics of sport
    - Sports performance factors
    - Metabolic performance characteristics
    - Performance characteristics during exercise
    - Specific adaptations of the organism to the load
    - Stress tests - introduction, performance characteristics of the athlete
    - Determination of thresholds (ventilation, lactate, circulating), Conconi test
    - Spiroergometry
    - PWC170
    - Selected tests of anaerobic assumptions (Jump ergometry, Wingate test)
    - Somatic characteristics of an athlete
    - Somatotype detection
    - Physiological essence of training, Health risks
    - Delivery of logs and worksheets
OBJECTIVES: The student will be able to understand the physiological processes in the organism during the sporting load and then after the physical activity. The graduate is able to explain logically and materially the structural and functional changes that occur in the organism due to adaptive mechanisms in response to a specific type of regular exercise load.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Regular enrollment of the subject and successful completion of so-called prerequisites in previous studies at FSpS (Anatomy and Physiology).
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Developed worksheets and exercise logs. The course will be finished by an oral exam.
TEACHING_METHODS: Lecture and practice. Exercises are both theoretical and practical, including laboratory testing. Teaching methods: presentation, discussion, demonstration of tests, practical measurements, homework (replenishment of worksheets).
TEACHER_INFO: v průběhu semestru studenti absolvují průběžný test o 12 otázkách. Pro splnění testu je nutné dosáhnout alespoň 75 % správných odpovědí. Úspěšné složení tohoto testu je nezbytnou podmínkou pro přístup ke zkoušce.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Graduates of the course will be able to:
    1.Describe the body's response to the load for specific groups of sports disciplines
    2. Identify the mechanisms of adaptation processes
    3. Analyze workload and load stress tests to determine the degree of stress and thus prevent the development of pathological fatigue.
LITERATURE:
BERNACIKOVÁ, Martina, Kateřina KAPOUNKOVÁ, Jan NOVOTNÝ, Eva SÝKOROVÁ, Jan NOVOTNÝ, Stanislav BERNACIK, Sylva HŘEBÍČKOVÁ, Eduard HRAZDÍRA, Pavel MUDRA, Jan ONDRÁČEK, Zora SVOBODOVÁ, Jaroslav ŠAMŠULA, Pavel VACENOVSKÝ a Jaroslava CHOVANCOVÁ.     Unilateral lower body exercises - hip dominant

ASSESMENT_METHODS: credit - written and graphique list of exercises, sample of selected techniques exercises, written test
TEACHING_METHODS: practical exercises supplemented by a theoretical explanation
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:
    - perform correct technique of strength exercises, diagnose errors in performance and correct them
    - create a stack of strengthening and stretching exercises for individual muscle parts with the use of equipment
    - apply the basics of the nomenclature of physical exercises with tools

Strength Training Anatomy

NAME: Classical Massage
TEACHERS: Grün, V. - Kapounková, K. - Struhár, I. - Müllerová, M. - Kopečková, B.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    1. Theoretical basics of massage
    2. Diseases of the subcutaneous tissue, musculoskeletal disorders and vertebral musculoskeletal disorders
    3. Indications and contraindications of massage
    4. General myology. Muscle system (back muscles, chest muscles, abdominal muscles, lower limb muscles)
    5. Types of massage, massage media
    6. Effects of massage - Effect on the skin, Effect on skeletal muscles, Effect on tendons, Effect on blood circulation, Effect on the lymphatic system
    7. Position of a person during massage, Pain and massage
    8. Classic Massage Technique: a) Effleurage b) Petrissage c) Friction d) Tapotement e) Vibration f) joint movements g) Various other forms
    9. Technical errors of massage therapist
    Seminars:
    1. Fundamentals of ergonomics of work
    2. Basic massage strokes - a) Effleurage b) Petrissage c) Friction d) Tapotement e) Vibration f) joint movements g) Various other forms
    3. Back massage including the shoulder blade (positioning, massage strokes, passive stretching)
    4. Neck massage including the shoulder blade (positioning, massage strokes, passive stretching)
    5. Lower limb massage (positioning, massage strokes, passive stretching)
OBJECTIVES: The main aim of the course is to administrate the massage of selected parts based on theoretical knowledge and practical skills. Another aim is to teach the student to choose the correct massage strokes with respect to the actual state of the person. Based on acquired knowledge, the student will analyze muscle groups, design and apply a combination of massage strokes based on their effectiveness. In conclusion, the student must justify used massage techniques.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. attendance (one absence is permitted)
    2. the final test. Minimum:70%
    3. Practical exam
TEACHING_METHODS:
- lectures
    - practical seminars
    Practical seminars are focused on the correct technique of individual massage strokes, which students practice in pairs under the supervision.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    1. Define general principles and benefits of massage
    2. List the indications and contraindications of the massage
    3. Define the topographic areas of the trunk and the lower limbs
    4. Choose the right massage strokes in relation to the aim of the massage
    5. Discuss about the selection of selected massage strokes
    6. Demonstrate individual massage strokes
    7. Practice selected massage - back, neck, lower limbs
    8. Assess the condition of the organism before and after massage
LITERATURE:
STORCK, Ulrich. Technika masáže v rehabilitaci. Edited by Heinz-Otto Junker - Walter Rostalski. 1. české vyd. Praha: Grada, 2010, 191 s. ISBN 9788024726632. URL info

1. Regeneration, regeneration, regeneration.
    2. Fatigue.
    3. Psychological means, pedagogical means of regeneration.
    4. Nutrition, basic concepts in nutrition, energy balance.
    5. Water, water balance, drinking regime.
    6. Vitamins and minerals.
    7. Nutrition in endurance sports.
    8. Nutrition in power sports.
    9. Food supplements - legislation, division.
    10. Food supplements - proteins, energy preparations, drinking regime, ergogenic substances.
OBJECTIVES: Get acquainted with basic regeneration methods. Within the framework of regeneration, focus more closely on nutrition. Successful graduates will be able to orientate themselves in possible regeneration methods and resources and basic principles of the nutrition plan for selected types of exercise and sports.

- attendance at seminars (1 is allowed), other absences require an official excuse via the study department
    - 3 subtests containing 5 questions with a total score of 15 points (10 points are required to meet the seminar requirements ... 70%)
    - 3 interim ROPOT in the form of open-book tests
    - the exam is written on a PC with a total of 30 points (at least 16 points are required for successful completion)
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: - Understand the concept of regeneration and the importance of nutrition for sportsmen, the concept of fatigue and adaptation. - Explain the basic concepts of nutrition, basic principles of regeneration. - Identify the need to establish a regeneration plan and a diet plan. NAME: Law in Sport
TEACHERS: Novák, J. - Novák, J.
SYLLABUS: 1 Application of basic legal standards in practice. 2 Understand the structure of internal standards within individual sports 3 Knowledge and application of basic contractual relationships in the sporting environment 4 Knowing the basics of budgeting of sports clubs and associations 5 Tax Issues in Associations and Business Companies 6 Knowledge and orientation on state administration portals 7 Management of general meetings of clubs and sports associations, activities of executive committees and committees 8 Pitfalls in the legal protection of physical and legal persons in sport 9 Basic understanding of the breadth and impact of self-responsibility in sporting activities 10 Knowledge of practices against the negative phenomena in sport - doping, corruption, betting, etc. 11 Basic differences in sports at schools, clubs and professional sports
OBJECTIVES: Learning outcomes of the course unit The aim of the course is to create a complex legal awareness of students about the Czech legal order, including the most important norms of European law, and to build legal awareness of students about the status of sport and its autonomous nature in the Czech and EU law. Furthermore, gaining a basic orientation in the creation and application of general and sporting standards in sports at the federal and commercial level and understanding the position of natural and legal persons in the governing structures of associations, both national and transnational, including acquisition of awareness of legal protection of sports subjects and responsibility in sport.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Experience in the creation, application and use of sports law.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: oral exam After passing lectures (to the extent necessary) and compulsory seminars, the student will receive a credit from the subject. The course is finished in written form. oral exam. In case the subject is not finished by the exam, the credit can not be awarded until the written test is completed. The rating scale for passing a test mark is A - F.
TEACHING_METHODS: lectures, seminar The subject is taught in the form of lectures and follow-up seminars. The lectures explain the basic topics of the given topic. The seminars discuss specific examples of current dispute and law practice. Due to the little-published comprehensive information about this issue, participation in lectures is a prerequisite for the completion of the course.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Upon completion of the course the students will be able to orientate in the Czech legal order in relation to sports subjects and the position of physical and legal persons in an autonomous sports environment. They will understand the notion of "state separation from sport" and the application of internal legal norms. For the future position of coaches, respectively. managers acquire knowledge of the responsibility in sport resulting from their activities in clubs and associations and all possibilities of legal protection within sports autonomy, including international institutions (CAS) and general courts, respectively. arbitration bodies.
LITERATURE:
Ústava ČR, ústavní zákon 1/1993 Sb. a Listina základních lidských práv a svobod - součást ústavního pořádku ČR, ústavní zákon 2/1993 Sb., Zákon č. 89/2012 Sb, občanský zákoník účinný od 1. 1. 2014.

NAME: Theory of Sports Training 2
TEACHERS: Langer, F. - Hrubý, M. - Hrubý, M. - Langer, F.
SYLLABUS: 1)TALENT – evaluation and forming talent, exogenous or endogenous factor, selection of talent. (example real selection) 2)METHODS OF MANIPULATING WITH LOADS – (construct by sort of sport) 3)MOTIVATION – primary, secondary, outer – inner, motive, needs (Maslow´s hierarchy of needs) SPORT MOTIVATION phase: generalization, differentiation, stabilization, diminution. 4)DIDACTIC METHODS orders, practical, reciprocal, self-evaluation, with offer, controlled discovering. 5)TYPOLOGY OF TRAINERS specialist, organiser, controller, motivator, educator-tutor. METHODS autocratic, democratic (participation), liberal, situational. 6)PRINCIPLES OF LEADING A TEAM, DIDACTIC PRINCIPLES – principles of a sport training 7)BIOLOGICAL QUANTITY FOR LEADING A SPORT TRAINING (heart rate, lactate, VO2 MAX) 8)TRAINING AT HIGH ALTITUDES – acclimatization 9)FITNESS, TECHNICAL AND PSYCHOLOGICAL PREPARATION – definition, aims, tasks, programs, methods and procedure. 10)MOVEMENT ACTIVITY AND TRAINING IN HIGHER AGE standards and recommendation for maintenance of condition, basics of workout (men, women. SPORT PREPARATION OF WOMEN, CHILDREN AND YOUTH) (principles, specifics from aspect of anatomy, physiology, psychology) 11)MOTORIC TESTS and their use, diagnostic, control, planning, prognostication, application methods of mathematics statistics. DIAGNOSTICS OF PHYSICAL FITNESS form of diagnostics, diagnostics methods a procedure, results of diagnostics from aspect of time. 12)ANALYSIS OF SPORT – GAME PERFORMANCE factors – determinants, movement activity and physiological characteristic, actual occurrence and trends of chosen discipline, sport (athletics, sport game, gymnastics, modern gymnastics, swimming), stimulation and development of dominant movement abilities. 13)PLANNING AND MODELING OF TRAINING LOAD stimulation and development of movement abilities: condition, coordination, hybrid, analyse of sport – game performance, individual and collective game performance, condition training, technical-tactical, regeneration, psychological preparation, kinetic tests, tests of sport skills.
OBJECTIVES: The main aim of TST is to, after successfully finishing this subject, clarify sport training (furthermore: pedagogical process with its specific didactics within sports like requirements in development of movement abilities in sport skills). Ability to use trainings methods, forms, preparation etc. with consideration the age, individualism to differences between gender, performance level in variable environment is prerequisite to required effectivity in training process or rather to reach maximal performance in some specific sport or discipline.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Written test using PC (close answers), condition to successfully pass the exam is 80% of the total score result for a particular test, active participation at the seminars,elaboration of a seminar paper on selected topic, and its PowerPoint presentation.
TEACHING_METHODS: Seminar teaching mixed, form outputs seminar for students on issues and practical activities for the development and performance of training
TEACHER_INFO: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/teorie-sportovniho-treninku-2/
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After finishing this subject every student should be able to: a)make a training plan for a specific load in some particular sport. b)create a movement activity plan in terms of health. c)explain and use basic principles of training in hypoxic environment. d)take into consideration differentness connected with growing up of children and youth people in training process. e)explain differences between sport training of a man and a woman and be able to use this knowledge in making training plans. f)Identify a sport talent g)Lead a training process in short-term, medium-term and long-term period. h) explain and use different kind of training for seniors and physical disabled people in practise use.

NAME: Field Testing and Measurements in Sport
TEACHERS: Vencúrik, T.
SYLLABUS:
Thematic units:
    - introduction to testing and measurement theory,
    - standardized tests, test systems and measurement recording,
    - tests of coordination abilities (reaction rate, balance,orientation, kinetic-differentiation ability) and flexibility,
    - strength and power tests (static and dynamic force, explosive force),
    - speed abilities tests (acceleration speed, frequency, maximum speed),
    - tests aimed at change of direction speed and agility,
    - tests on the ability of repeated sprints,
    - endurance tests (anaerobic endurance and aerobic endurance),
    - processing and evaluation of data obtained from testing and measurement,
    - interpretation and comparison of data obtained from testing and measurement.
OBJECTIVES: To gain knowledge about basic measurement methods and construction of field tests and how to use them to acquire the skills and experience needed for measuring and testing in physical education and sport.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Basic knowledge from anthropomotorics (bp4018) and methodology of sport science (bp4001).
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. 80% attendance,
    2. e-test,
    3. practical demonstration of students from testing and measuring in a selected sport
    4. report from testing session
TEACHING_METHODS:
Practical seminars where students will perform selected tests.
    Self-study.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After successfully completing the course student will:
    - have basic knowledge of field test theory and measurement,
    - know the difference between standardized and non-standardized tests,
    - be able to choose a suitable standardized test for motor ability testing,
    - know the procedure of standardized tests of coordination abilities and will be able to use it in practice,
    - know the procedure of standardized tests of strength and conditioning abilities and will be able to use it in practice,
    - have knowledge of motor skills tests,
    - know testing systems for fitness assessment,
    - be able to evaluate the risks of testing and measurement, and will be able to identify factors that may influence test performance,
    - have an overview of the instruments and devices used for testing and measurement,
    - be able to record, process and evaluate the data obtained from testing and measurement,
    - be able to interpret acquired data and compare it with standards and data from other research.
LITERATURE:
Essentials of strength training and conditioning. Edited by Greg Haff - N. Travis Triplett. Fourth edition. Champaign, Ill.: Human Kinetics, 2016, xvi, 735. ISBN 9781492501626. info
        MORROW, James R., Dale MOOD, James G. DISCH a Minsoo KANG. Measurement and evaluation in human performance. Fifth edition. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics, 2016, xv, 463. ISBN 9781450470438. info

NAME: Sports Psychology and Working with Clients
TEACHERS: Pačesová, P.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4017 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS: Sport psychology, historical development, recent situation. psychologie sportu • Professiography, psycho-sportography. Laterality. • Personality of the athlete, diagnostic process, classification. Temperament. • Motivation, basic theories. Need for achievement. Assessment. Aspiration. • Sociální skupina a sport - charakteristika, utváření, působení, dynamika Social groups, teams. Characteristics, features, dynamic development. Social influence: innovation, conformity, authority, decision making. Stages of the group development. The regulations, norms. • Individual and the team. Roles. Leader. • Executive functions, motor intellect. • Psyche and top achievement. Self-awareness, the goals, activation - relaxation. • Psyche and top achievement. stress, fear, anxiety and competition. Emotion, aggression, dynamic processes and sports. • Motor learning, specific theories. Faces, plato, process of the forgetting. Flow. Asertivity and sports activities. • Advising: definition, principles, approaches: consulting, manipulative, directive. - Meeting client: the goal, diagnostic process, SMART technique. - Communication: talking - hearing, questioning, interview, solving of model situations. -Self-reflection. Coaching: the goals, principles, means. Dyadic interaction, team interaction. • Team management, atmosphere in the team. Team atmosphere. Team regulations and norms. Personal development of the athletes. Principles of spiritual hygiene.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to reserve the basic information focuses on psychology knowledge into sport setting: recreation, top competitive, physical education. The aim is oriented on issues linked with psychical processes in mentioned environment within dyadic and team network, on the topics: professional, motor competencies etc. Next aim is to underline the topics of the individual approaches to individuals from different social groups and in various life situations, issue of consulting, interactive approaches to client.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Passing the course bp4017 Psychology
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 80% participation on interactive seminars written test - open questions, 60% of successful answers - - with discussion and feedback
TEACHING_METHODS: theoretical lectures, seminars, class discussion, self-work, ppt. presentation
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After the course student is able to - use the knowledge in the field practice, - to analyze the personality features and behavior (athlete, coach), - recognize learning processes and motor learning, - demonstrate the regulation of psychic level in relation in sports loading, - to solve conflict situation in the team, - to analyze psychical needs of the individual and his/her goals, - to presents communicative skills in relation on client situation, - to cope, solve the individual problems within sports and healthy life style environment.

NAME: Patophysiology of Exercise
TEACHERS: Bernaciková, M. - Dobrovolná, J. - Kapounková, K. - Pospíšil, Z. - Vomela, J. - Bernaciková, M. - Grün, V. - Řehoř, A.
SYLLABUS:
Syllabus of lectures:
    Fundamentals of genetics (genetic code, replication, transcription and translation of DNA, chromosomes). DNA diagnostics.
    Pathophysiology of cell and cell interactions (apoptosis, necrosis, disease factors).
    General manifestations of disease (fever, pain, inflammation).
    Pathophysiology of stress (fatigue).
    Acidobasic equilibrium disorders.
    Disorders of carbohydrate metabolism (DM).
    Disorders of lipid metabolism (hyperlipoproteinemia, hypolipoproteinemia). Pathophysiology of atherosclerosis.
    Disorders of nucleotide metabolism (arthritis uratica, tumor breakdown syndrome). Disorders of hem and iron metabolism.
    Consequences of hypokinesia. Some systemic manifestations of lack of physical activity.
    Metabolic syndrome (definitions, signs, causes of onset).
    Dysregulation of food intake and body weight (with negative energy balance, positive energy balance).
    Acute damage in sports. Types of injuries. causes and mechanisms of injuries in sport due to the specificities of selected sports disciplines.
    Chronic damage in sports.
    Psychosomatics
    Syllabus of exercises:
    Influence of genetics on physical activity and obesity (human genome, sports genes, obesity genes, epigenetics, genetic tests etc.).
    Influenced biological factors of preanalytical variability in biochemical sampling (race, sex, genetic factors, pregnancy, biorhythms, weight, lifestyle, physical load, diet, smoking).
    Biochemical markers of inflammation (C-reactive protein, cytokines).
    Biological indicators of fatigue. Questionnaire for fatigue manifestations (physiological + psychological) + its evaluation.
    Subjective feelings, speaking test (practically).
    Biochemical indicators of acid-base balance disorders (buffer systems, BE, PH, PO2, pCO2).
    Selected stress tests and monitoring of physiological functions of carbohydrate metabolism disorders (oral glucose tolerance test - oGTT, monitoring of glycemia in motion activity - glucometers, biosensors).
    Monitoring of physiological functions in lipid metabolism disorders (cholesterol, triacylglycerols, adiponectin, ghrelin, leptin). Ultrasound.
    Metabolic syndrome - risk factors (anthropometric indicators, blood pressure measurements, biochemical indicators).
    Anthropometric indicators (fat component, muscle component, bone density).
    Risk analysis of injuries in relation to sports disciplines. Prevention principles.
    Physical activity during pregnancy (recommendation) and postpartum (including diastase and umbilical hernia - practical demonstration).
    Physiology and pathophysiology of running on runway and outdoors - practically.
    Physiology and pathophysiology during treadmill and bicycle trekking. - practically
OBJECTIVES: The graduate will be able to understand the basic physiological and pathological processes of people with sedentary lifestyles. The graduate will also be able to think creatively about the possible consequences of physical activity on the human body. Not only in the field of biological effects on individual systems, but also in the area of possible pathophysiological impact of regular specific sports load (both acute and chronic).
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 90% active participation in exercises. Student graduates. - 2 written tests. tests consist of   10 questions rated 20 points. To achieve successful mastery, it is necessary to achieve 14. - the working sheets drawn up and handed over. The whole subject is finished by an oral exam, evaluated by the A-F scale.
TEACHING_METHODS: Lecture and practice. Exercises are both theoretical and practical, including laboratory testing. Teaching methods: presentation, discussion, demonstration of tests, practical measurements, homework (replenishment of worksheets).
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
The graduate will be able to:
    1. explain the issue of hypokinesis in relation to possible system changes of the organism and their health consequences
    2. recommend basic stress and biochemical examinations in relation to possible weakness resulting from   hypokinesia
    3. to list and describe possible injuries and typical chronic injuries in selected sports disciplines
LITERATURE:
OTOVÁ, Berta a František SOUKUP. Základy genetiky (Obsaž.) : Biologie člověka pro bakalářské studium na lékařských fakultách. info
        STEJSKAL, Pavel. Metabolický syndrom – mezioborový problém. 1. vyd. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2014, 107 s. ISBN 978-80-210-7539-9. info

NAME: Nutrition
TEACHERS: Hlinský, T. - Kumstát, M. - Kovářová, K. - Wagner, A.
SYLLABUS:
01. The importance of nutrition for the human organism
    02. History, assessment of nutritional status and nutritional recommendations
    03. Energy balance
    04. Carbohydrates, proteins, fats I – their importance in nutrition and recommendations
    05. Carbohydrates, proteins, fats II – their importance in nutrition and recommendations
    06. Vitamins and minerals – their importance in nutrition and recommendations
    07. Hydration and fluid intake
    08. Specifics of population groups I - Nutrition of children, adults, seniors
    09. Specifics of population groups II - Nutrition of physically active individuals
    10. Nutrition in prevention and disease
    11. Alternative nutritional directions

OBJECTIVES: Learning outcomes of the course unit The aim of the subject is to acquaint students with nutritional recommendations for the normal healthy population and for the population with increased physical load. To get acquainted with the basic components of human nutrition, their importance, sources, benefits and physiological effects. Understand the role of water and drinking in human nutrition. Introduce them to basic alternative nutritional directions and diets.

NAME: Kinesiology
TEACHERS: Bartošová, S. - Bazalová, P. - Vomáčková, K. - Vysoký, R.
SYLLABUS:
Motor control - cortical, subcortical and spinal level. Basic techniques of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation and inhibition.
    Kinesiology of soft tissues of locomotor apparatus - skin, subdermal tissue, fascia, muscle, cartilage.
    Kinesiology of hard tissues of locomotor apparatus - bone.
    Kinesiology of upper extremity - basic motor patterns
    Kinesiology of lower extremity - basic motor patterns
OBJECTIVES: The aim of Kinesiology lectures is to introduce students to human locomotor system from the perspective of motor control and soft and hard tissues of locomotor system itself. Motor control is presented as multi level from cortical control towards spinal incl. ontogenesis of gross and fine motorics. Human motor system is also explained from the topographical point as particular motor segments incl. physiology of adaptation and maladaptation to work load. Global postural reactions and movement patterns are axplained.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 2 written tests in the course of a term and one final written test. 70% of correct answers is needed to pass.
TEACHING_METHODS: Frontal type of education with open discussion to presented topics.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Successful students will achieve basic knowledge of motor control incl. optional therapeutical interventions. They will know mechanisms of adaptation and maladaptation of motor tissues to work load. Students will understand basic topographic anatomy and physiology of particular motor segments of human body.
LITERATURE:

NAME: Team Skills
TEACHERS: Heiland Trávníková, D. - Šíp, R.
SYLLABUS:
Definition of a team (structure, roles, needs, competences of team members)
    Team goals
    Team skills
    Team roles
    Communication and cooperation in team
    Group dynamics
    Conflict in a group, crisis in a team
    Decision making, working in a team X working in a group
    Team leader, team motivation, team evaluation
    Feedback and reflection
OBJECTIVES:
Students of Sports Management should be aware of the importance of team skills as a necessary aspect of team work.
    The objective of this course is to introduce the students into the field of team skills, team roles, team goals and team characteristics. Students will also understand additional topics, such as effective communication and cooperation, providing feedback and evaluation. Group dynamics phases and team motivation will be covered as well. The topics will be presented through practical activites and games, with necessary theoretical background.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. Active participation in lectures and seminars (MAX 1 absence accepted)
    2. Presentation (10 min) of an activity focused on a selected team skill. The activity will be performed with the study group. More information to be found in "Homework vault".
    3. Handing in a lesson plan of the presented activity
    4. Final written test
TEACHING_METHODS: Lectures, practical seminars, group work, group discussion, feedback and evaluation activites
TEACHER_INFO: Reflection of group work Odevzdávárna (homework vault) open till ...!
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completion of this course students will be able to:
    -name and describe basic team skills (communication, cooperation, flexibility, presentation of ideas, feedback and evaluation, creativity)
    -define team structure, team goals, team roles and important aspects of an effective team cooperation
    -describe group dynamics phases and manage a team/group accordingly
    -analyse their status within the study group, from the point of view of team roles, communication or cooperation level (based on practical activities and exercises)
    -apply the acquired knowledge and skills in a working, sports or other team

NAME: Sports Management
TEACHERS: Racek, O. - Dr. Sujit Chaudhuri - Kyselica, A. - Racek, O.
SYLLABUS: Introduction to Strategic Management- the necessity of strategic and financial planning, basic strategic management concepts and models in the global sports industry; 2. Strategic environment: Market environment, PESTEL analysis, Porter's five forces model,sporting market models and their strategic implications, the concentration of capital and market niches in sport; 3. The role of the state in the development of the sport - the reasons for government intervention, regulation control, the extent of state intervention; 4. The non-profit sector and sport - the role of the nonprofit sector in sport , organizations in the nonprofit sector for the sport. 5. Professional sport - the concept, the role of media, management of athletes, evaluation of results; 6. The principles of strategic management and strategic choice in sports - the basis of competitive advantage, strategy, diversification, value chain analysis, SWOT / TOWS matrix analysis and RACES; 7. Organizational and strategic changes – conditions of internal organization in sports, archetypes of the dynamics of changes in the internal organization of sports organizations for the implementation of the chosen strategy; 8. Human resources management in sport – specifics of the management and evaluation of human resources in sport organizations; 9. Leadership - Leadership Theory, differences between manager and leader and their implications in the management of sports organizations; 10. Organizational culture in sports - specifics and importance of organizational culture in sport, subculture, organizational identity, diagnosis and management of changes in the organizational culture of sport organizations; 11. Financial management of sports organizations - financial resources in sport, information for financial management and their importance to the management of sports organizations; 12. Strategy Implementation - from the perspective of the marketing, organization and financial management; 13. Performance evaluation in sport – specifics of the performance evaluation in sports organization, multidimensional approach to performance evaluation and its criteria.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to acquaint students with the specifics of strategic management in sports organizations in the public, professional and non-profit sector of sport.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Defense of the seminar work and its presentation • written exam assessed according to the quality of answers
TEACHING_METHODS: Lectures and seminars with the key element - a discussion of case studies and group presentations by the ongoing tasks. Individual preparation for the seminars - studying the case study of sport organizations, an active discussion so that the students develop and strengthen their understanding of the problems and enable sharing their ideas in the framework of the learning process. Structured selfstudy will form the basis of seminar activities. Selfstudy will be based on the presentation of case studies in strategic sports management and will provide cross section of the strategic management issues of various sports governing bodies, professional sports clubs and other organizations
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After the successful completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. understand the different models of the processes of strategic management of sports organizations and discuss the relevance of these models, taking into account the specifics of the sport; 2. critically analyze the key features of the current strategic management in the sports environment; 3. identify strategic decisions of managers in sport organizations 4. critically evaluate strategic options of sports organizations, including their feasibility and sustainability; 5. identify problems and opportunities the sports organizations are facing when implementing their chosen strategies
LITERATURE:

NAME: Sports Marketing
TEACHERS: Racek, O. - Kyselica, A. - Racek, O.
SYLLABUS:
1. Marketing and sport marketing - definition, development
    2. Marketing environment
    3. Marketing strategies and planning
    4. Target markets and their segmentation
    5. Marketing mix and its specifics in sport
    6. Sponsoring
    7. Sports advertising and merchandising
    8. Ambush Marketing and Guerilla Marketing
OBJECTIVES: Learning outcomes of the course unit The aim of the course is to acquaint students with the issues of marketing and its application to the sporting environment. Explain the specifics in analyzing the marketing environment and preparing the marketing mix of the sport product.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The final exam is written.
    The student will be admitted to the examination if he/she presents the seminar paper properly and submits it on time (i.e. obtains 60-100%). He/she also submits on time 10 short extracts from professional articles that he/she has read during the semester.
    For the seminar paper and its presentation, the student may receive 10 points for the exam. The student may earn an additional 5 points for the exam for the abstracts (see study materials).
    Evaluation:
    A - 100-90 % B - 89-85 % C - 84-75 % D - 74-70 % E - 69-60 %
    If a student commits any disciplinary infraction, that action will be considered a failure to meet the requirements for completion of the course. The instructor will close the examination (credit) with a grade of "F" in the IS and the Dean will initiate disciplinary proceedings which may result in termination.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Teaching is conducted in the form of lectures and seminars.
    In the seminars, actual case studies will be dealt with and discussion of the issues is expected.
    The student will prepare and present a seminar paper on the topic.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Student will be able to:
    - Explain the concept of marketing and its specifics in the sporting environment - to enumerate and explain the factors of the marketing environment - Apply marketing mix tools in a particular case - Create a sponsorship offer - Apply guerilla marketing practices in the preparation of marketing strategy
LITERATURE:

NAME: Strength Training and Conditioning in Individual Sports
TEACHERS: Cacek, J. - Králová, T. - Kalina, T. - Hrubý, M. - Roček, M. - Mojžíš, M. - Králová, T. - Kalina, T. - Morávek, Z.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_kondcvic )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    Specifics of strength and conditional training in individual sports.
    Strength and conditional training in short-term lasting functionally mobilizing sports. (sprints, throws, shot put, weight lifting).
    Strength and conditional training in long term lasting functionally mobilizing sports. (cycling, long distance running).
    Strength and conditional training in risks sports. (skiing, bobsled).
    Strength and conditional training in anticipation sports. (martial arts, fencing, tennis)
    Strength and conditional training in aesthetic- coordination sports (gymnastic).
    Strength and conditional training in senzory sports. (golf).
    Recomendation for physical activity in common population.
    Monitoring of fitness and physical activity in common population.
    Seminars:
    Preparation of training plans for selected individual sports.
    Preparation of motion programs for common population.
    evidence of training and physical activity of common population.
    Examples of excersises, methods, development and stabilization, of specific training in individual selected sports
    Examples of excersises, methods of development and stabilization of fitness in common population.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of subject is provide knowledge about specifics of strength and coditional training in selected sports with development of physical fitness. The another goal is to educate students with planning, periodization and leading of conditional training in selected groups.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Completion of subject Periodization and planning of training.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The exam consists of two parts.
    The first part is the preparation (individual, group work) of plans for training units, microcycles, mesocycles or macrocycles in a specified sport discipline or selected population group (the distribution of specific topics will take place during the first week of the semester). Students will upload the developed topic to the appropriate drop box no later than 2 days prior to the specific due date determined at the beginning of the semester. They then present the developed training plan along with the basic background of fitness training for the topic/sport/population and demonstrate the selected training unit in the seminar. The preparation and implementation of the identified plan and training unit A-F is assessed. The seminar output assessment accounts for 30% of the overall course grade.
    The second part is a written and subsequent oral examination in which the student draws one of the individual sports. For this sport, the student will describe the background of fitness training and design training plans according to the assignment, which he/she will defend orally immediately after the written preparation. The examination grade is A-F, with the examination accounting for 70% of the overall grade for the course.
TEACHING_METHODS: Theory and practical excersises, planning motion and training programs.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After succesfull of the subject student will be able to:
    to interprete basic of planning and periodization of strength and conditional training in individual sports.
    to apply structure of sports perfomance factors on concrete sports perfomance in selected sports or disciplines.
    to realize plans of strength and conditional training in common population and in selected spotrs.

NAME: Olympic Weightlifting
TEACHERS: Králová, T. - Morávek, Z.
SYLLABUS:
- Introduction to excersise with olympic bar, manipulation with dumbells and loading dumbells on bar, rules.
    - Safety and individual help.
    - squat with olympic bar (front, back, overhead,..).
    - Basic position at individual weightlifting excersises.
    - Methods of snatch training.
    - methods of clean and jerk training.
    - Nomenclature of weight lifting excersises.
    - Theoretical basic of weightlifting excersises.
    - Identification of incorrect execution of weightlifting exercises and its correction
OBJECTIVES: The aim of subject is educate students about weight-lifting knowledge and skills. (basic of nomenclature, technique of weight lifting, excersise with olympic bar, diagnostic of mistakes and their elimination).
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The credit consists of two parts.
    The first part is a written test (10 questions, 75% correct answers are required to pass, the assessment is pass/fail; the test can be repeated 3 times). The test focuses on weightlifting rules, weightlifting methodology and exercise terminology.
    The second part of the credit consists of a practical demonstration of a competitive execution of a snatch and clean and jerk in a real competition according to the rules of weightlifting. The selected competition will be announced during the first class of the semester. The assessment for the practical credit is pass/fail, where pass means successful completion of the selected competition (in the Olympic weightlifting). The weight of the lowest base for start weight in the competition is limited by the weightlifting rules (women = 21 kg; men 26 kg).
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After succesfull completion student will be able:
    to demonstrate technique of snatch and jerk
    to identify mistakes in technique of weightlifting excersises, to propose and suggest procedure of their elimination
    to demonstrate training methodology of snatch and jerk, including with specific, preparatory excersises with olympic bar
    to apply the structure of training weight lifting excersises, including their modifications

NAME: Primary Prevention of Chronic Non-Communicable Diseases
TEACHERS: Kapounková, K. - Vysoký, R. - Vysoký, R.
SYLLABUS:
Overview of lecture topics:
    Health and disease. Definition of health. Definition of illness.
    Basic determinants of health. Health promotion.
    The importance and objectives of prevention in the field of chronic noninfectious diseases
    Stages of disease development and inclusion of all levels of prevention (principle, meaning).
    Lifestyle and the emergence of civilization diseases. Quality of life in relation to health.
    Targeted assistance with regard to specific individual needs.
    System, characteristics and organization of preventive programs (planning, finance).
    Evaluation of preventive programs (short-term and long-term effect of the program).
    World Health Organization (WHO establishment and operation, health programs implemented in the Czech Republic, health 2020)

    Overview of seminar topics:
    Organization of preventive programs (planning, finance, creation of a crisis intervention system).
    Evaluation of preventive programs (short-term and long-term effect of the program).
    Preventive examinations and examinations. Screening examinations in primary care.
    Quality of life in relation to health (evaluation methods).
OBJECTIVES: Course graduates should be able to logically think about prevention as a tool to contribute to the sustainable development of humanity and life. Course graduates should acquire knowledge of the active influence of risk factors for the emergence of civilization diseases.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 90% active participation in seminars • Creation of a preventive health promotion project according to the assignment, evaluated by A-F scale • Oral examination of the quality assessment of the area, assessed by the A-F scale
TEACHING_METHODS: Theoretical and practical lessons in the form of lectures and seminars.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Graduates of the course will be able to:
    1. search for existing prevention programs
    2. Evaluate current prevention programs
    3. evaluate the results of the preventive examinations
    4. Focus on strategic recommendations on health promotion

TEACHERS: Müllerová, M. - Struhár, I.
SYLLABUS:
1. Ergonomics of work. Repetition of tactics and assemblies from classic massage (Lower limb massage, back massage including scapula, Massage of the neck including scapula, Massage of the upper limbs, Massage of the abdomen)
    2. Role of masseur in preparation for sports performance
    3. Determination of basic anamnestic data necessary for the realization of massage 4. Measuring range of motion
    5. Communication between a masseur and an athlete in terms of preparing an athlete for performance
    6. Pre-event massage
    7. Massage in breaks between performances
    8. Massage after sport performance and its specifics
    9. Sport massage in speed-power sports
    10. Sport massage in endurance sports
    11. Sports massage in sports games
    12. Sports massage in aesthetic-coordinating and combo sports
    13. Sports injuries and massage applications
OBJECTIVES: The main goal of this course is to provide students practical skills in the field of using sports massage as a means of regeneration. Within the framework of the lessons, we will focus on improving the practical application of the massage strokes from the Classical massage. We will also focus on the art of palpation (both surface and deep). The course is also focused on practical differentiation of soft tissues and palpation.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Successful completion of subjects Classical Massage and Anatomy
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. attendance (one absence is permitted)
    2. 2 tests during semester, min.65 %
    3. Practical exam
TEACHING_METHODS: 1. Theoretical part 2. Practical part focused on the right application of sport massage with correction of qualified practitioner
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    1. to identify the appropriate type of sports massage with regard to goals
    2. to assess the current state of the locomotive system
    3. to explain the choice of the chosen sport massage
    4. to discuss the choice of used tactics in a sports massage
    5. to practice a sports massage before, in a break of unfinished performance and after the completion of the physical activity
    6. to design a regeneration protocol with respect to the athlete's physical load and physical activity
    7. to evaluate the athlete's status based on the subjective feeling before and after the application of the selected type of sports massage
    8. to evaluate the athlete's current readiness for performance in relation to objective parameters such as measuring range of motion
LITERATURE:
MCGILLICUDDY, Michael. Massage for sport performance. Champaign, Ill.: Human Kinetics, 2011, ix, 181. ISBN 9780736083010. info
        STORCK, Ulrich. Technika masáže v rehabilitaci. Edited by Heinz-Otto Junker - Walter Rostalski. 1. české vyd. Praha: Grada, 2010, 191 s. ISBN 9788024726632. URL info
        MÜLLER-WOHLFAHRT, Hans-Wilhelm. Muscle injuries in sports. Stuttgart: Thieme, 2013, xix, 417. ISBN 9783131624710. info

        RICHTER, Philipp a Eric HEBGEN. Spouštěcí body a funkční svalové řetězce v osteopatii a manuální terapii. Praha: Pragma, 2011, 237 s. ISBN 9788073492618. info
        BUSCHBACHER, Ralph M., Nathan D. PRAHLOW a Shashank J. DAVE. Sports medicine and rehabilitation : A sport-specific approach. 2nd ed. Philadelphia: Wolters Kluwer/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, 2009, xii, 285. ISBN 9780781777452. info

NAME: Nutritional Counselling
TEACHERS: Hlinský, T. - Kumstát, M.
SYLLABUS:
01. Introduction to nutritional programming
    02. Evolutionary context of nutrition in human health
    03. Medical history
    04. Methods of assessing nutritional status
    05. Qualitative and quantitative aspects of nutrition
    06. Nutritional recommendations
    07. Child nutrition
    08. Nutrition of pregnant and lactating women
    09. Nutrition of the elderly
    10. Role of nutrition and lifestyle in primary prevention
    11. Role of nutrition in secondary and tertiary prevention
    12. Allergies and intolerances
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to introduce students to methods of nutritional status assessment, tools for assessing dietary habits and aspects of counselling. An integral part of nutritional programming, namely planning, is the acquisition of skills not only in dietary analysis but especially in dietary modification, suggesting changes, and interpreting results to clients from different population groups.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Students build on the knowledge acquired in bp4013 Physiology, bp4063 Physiology of Nutrition and bp4062 Nutrition.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Students are graded A-F based on meeting the prerequisites below:
    1. Active participation in seminars (2 absences allowed).
    2. Completion of a portfolio, which is a requirement for admission to the examination, to the following extent:
    a) Semester project in the form of a comprehensive text document according to the template. The content will be an analysis and evaluation of the nutritional status and dietary habits of the selected case study, together with a proposal for recommendations;
    b) completion of the Peer Review of the semester project;
    c) continuous completion of the sub-assigned independent work as assigned in the interactive curriculum.
    3. Interim tests verifying knowledge of the studied areas (3 in total). The tests are taken at the time of the seminar every fourth week of the semester. The maximum number of points obtained in all tests is 30. For credit to be awarded, at least 75% of the maximum score must be obtained (at least 22 points).
    4. Passing the oral examination.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Theoretical support is preferably the content of lectures and independent work - self-study of interactive study aids (in the scope of about 1 hour/week).
    Practical teaching is implemented in the form of seminars with open discussion and thematic workshops. It will include:
    - group work,
    - case study analysis,
    - application of knowledge to work with population groups.
    Independent work based on the seminar teaching will be based on completing homework exercises and assignments, submitting them to the appropriate submission room, and completing answer sheets and course projects involving peer assessment.
LITERATURE:
RAWSON, Eric S., J. David BRANCH a Tammy J. STEPHENSON. Williams' nutrition for health, fitness & sport. Thirteenth edition. New York: McGraw Hill, 2024, 1 online. ISBN 9781266492150. URL info
        HOLEČEK, Milan. Regulace metabolismu základních živin u člověka. Druhé, upravené vydání,. Praha: Univerzita Karlova v Praze, nakladatelství Karolinum, 2016, 251 stran. ISBN 9788024629766. info
        KASPER, Heinrich a Walter BURGHARDT. Výživa v medicíně a dietetika. Edited by Walter Burghardt, Translated by Karel Procházka. 1. české vydání. Praha: Grada, 2015, xiii, 572. ISBN 9788024745336. info
        KLIMEŠOVÁ, Iva a Jiří STELZER. Fyziologie výživy. 1. vyd. Olomouc: Univerzita Palackého v Olomouci, 2013, 177 s. ISBN 9788024432809. info

NAME: Nutritional Counselling in Sport
TEACHERS: Kumstát, M. - Hlinský, T. - Puda, D.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to apply and modify aquired knowledge of basic principles of nutrition to the variable sports preparation and competition in an effort to support training adaptation, regeneration and sport performance.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Students are graded A-F based on meeting the prerequisites below:
    1. Active participation in seminars (2 absences allowed).
    2. Completion of a portfolio, which is a requirement for admission to the examination, to the following extent:
    a) Semester project in the form of a comprehensive text document according to the template. The content will be an analysis and evaluation of the nutritional status and dietary habits of the selected case study, together with a proposal for recommendations;
    b) Completion of the Semester Project Peer Review;
    c) continuous completion of the sub-assigned independent work as assigned in the interactive curriculum.
    3. Interim tests verifying knowledge of the studied areas (3 in total). The tests are taken at the time of the seminar every fourth week of the semester. The maximum number of points obtained from all tests is 30. To be awarded credit, at least 75% of the maximum score (at least 22 points) must be obtained.
    4. Passing the oral examination.
TEACHING_METHODS:
The theoretical basis of the subject is primarily delivered through lectures and home-study, including self-directed use of the interactive syllabus (approximately 1 hour per week).
    Practical instruction is conducted through seminars featuring open discussions and thematic workshops. These will involve group work, peer analysis of case studies, and applying findings to work with various athletes. Independent study, building on seminar content, will include completing homework exercises and assignments, submitting them through the designated submission portal, and finishing answer sheets and course projects.

NAME: Athlete Regeneration
TEACHERS: Kapounková, K. - Krajňák, J. - Kumstát, M. - Lipková, L. - Puda, D. - Struhár, I.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    -Regeneration - fundamental concepts
    -Stress reaction
    -Regenerative form
    -Acute and chronic fatique
    -Regenerative pedagogical means
    -Regenerative psychological means
    -Regenerative biological means
    -Regenerative pharmacological means
    -Physiological and pathological fatigue
    -Physiological aspect of the motion
    Seminars:
    -Postural stability and deep stabilization system- injury prevention, practical demonstration
    -Stress testing of the athlete (demonstration of protocols + subsequent analysis of data)
    -Isokinetic testing in relation to sports regeneration
    -Using of compression garments in relation to performance and athlete´s regeneration
    -Influence of negative thermotherapy and its application in sport
    -The use of selected forms of hydrotherapy in athlete´s regeneration
    -Myofascial release with using foamrollers
OBJECTIVES: Main objectives can be summarized as follows: the basic knowledge about regeneration; to delineate the major differences between passive and active regeneration; to understand the physiologic process of organism in the course regeneration; to understand the chronological process of regeneration; to understand the chanching regeneration of the type in the sports motion to make the regeneration plane for athletic discipline
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. Attendance (two absence is permitted)
    2. Regularly preparation at seminars
    3. Test. Test comprises 30 questions. When a student answers a question correctly, he/she is awarded a point for it. To pass the test, the student must reach the score of at least 21 points.
    4. Exam
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    1. to explain the difference between active and passive recovery
    2. to analyse the athlete training loads
    3. to design a suitable type of regeneration for the expected type of fatigue
LITERATURE:
BERNACIKOVÁ, Martina, Jan CACEK, Lenka DOVRTĚLOVÁ, Iva HRNČIŘÍKOVÁ, Kateřina KAPOUNKOVÁ, Jitka KOPŘIVOVÁ, Michal KUMSTÁT, Jan NOVOTNÝ, Petr POSPÍŠIL, Jana ŘEZANINOVÁ, Michal ŠAFÁŘ a Tomáš ULBRICH. Regenerace a výživa ve sportu. 1. vyd. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2013, 252 s. ISBN 978-80-210-6253-5. info

        Recovery for performance in sport. Edited by Christophe Hausswirth - Iñigo Mujika. Champaign, Ill.: Human Kinetics, 2013, xi, 281. ISBN 9781450434348. info

NAME: Management and Marketing in Sport
TEACHERS: Racek, O. - Racek, O.
SYLLABUS:
1. The environment of sports management
    2. The role of the state in the development of sport
    3. Strategic management in sport
    4. Non-profit sector and sport
    5. Professional sport
    6. Organizational culture in sport
    7. Sport marketing - definition, development
    8. Marketing environment in sport
    9. Target markets and their segmentation
    10. Marketing mix and its specifics in sport
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to introduce students to the environment of sport management and marketing, to orient them properly and to apply the acquired theoretical knowledge to sports practice.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The final exam is written.
    Students will be admitted to the exam if they properly present and submit a seminar paper (ie 60% - 100%). The evaluation of the seminar paper and its presentation is a third of the final evaluation.

    Rating:
    A - 100% - 90%
    B - 89% - 85%
    C - 84% - 75%
    D - 74% - 70%
    E - 69% - 60%

    If a student commits any disciplinary offense, this behavior will be deemed not to meet the conditions for terminating the subject. The lecturer enters the exam (assessment) in the IS with a mark "F" and the dean initiates disciplinary proceedings, resulting in the completion of studies.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Teaching is conducted in the form of lectures and seminars.
    In the seminars the current case studies will be dealt with, the discussion of the issue is expected.
    The student will prepare and present a seminar paper.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Student will be able to:
    - describe the environment of sports management
    - to explain the role of the state in the development of sport
    - Apply strategic management tools in practice
    - to discuss the issue of professional sport
    - define marketing and explain its specifics in the sport environment
    - Apply marketing mix tools in a particular case.
LITERATURE:
NOVÁ, Jana, Jiří NOVOTNÝ, Oldřich RACEK, Jaroslav REKTOŘÍK, Aleš SEKOT, Milena STRACHOVÁ a Hana VÁLKOVÁ. Management, marketing a ekonomika sportu. 1. vyd. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2016, 284 s. ISBN 978-80-210-8346-2. Online knihkupectví Munipress info

NAME: Sports Psychology and Coaching
TEACHERS: Pačesová, P.
SYLLABUS: Sport psychology, historical development, recent situation. psychologie sportu • Professiography, psycho-sportography. Laterality. • Personality of the athlete, diagnostic process, classification. Temperament. • Motivation, basic theories. Need for achievement. Assessment. Aspiration. • Sociální skupina a sport - charakteristika, utváření, působení, dynamika Social groups, teams. Characteristics, features, dynamic development. Social influence: innovation, conformity, authority, decision making. Stages of the group development. The regulations, norms. • Individual and the team. Roles. Leader. • Executive functions, motor intellect. • Psyche and top achievement. Self-awareness, the goals, activation - relaxation. • Psyche and top achievement. stress, fear, anxiety and competition. Emotion, aggression, dynamic processes and sports. • Motor learning, specific theories. Faces, plato, process of the forgetting. Flow. Asertivity and sports activities. • Coaching: the goals, principles, means. Dyadic interaction, team interaction. • Team management, atmosphere in the team. Team atmosphere. Team regulations and norms. Personal development of the athletes. Principles of spiritual hygiene.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to reserve the basic information focuses on psychology knowledge into sport setting: recreation, top competitive, physical education. The aim is oriented on issues linked with psychical processes in mentioned environment within dyadic and team network. Next aim is to present the topics from coaching domain as the mean of the development personality and the team.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 80 % - participation in seminars home-works - assessed with points Written test - open questions
TEACHING_METHODS: Interactive lectures with support of IT, seminars, self-study, class discussion
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: After the course student is able to - use the knowledge in the field practice, - to analyze the personality features and behavior (athlete, coach), - recognize learning processes and motor learning, - demonstrate the regulation of psychic level in relation in sports loading, - to solve conflict situation in the team, - to analyze team atmosphere, - to apply basic coaching skills.
LITERATURE:

1. Kind of injuries – after body regions, organs and causes
    2. Causes of th injuries in sport (after kind of sport)
    3. Analyse of sports after risks of the injuries
    4. Rules of the prevention of the injuries.
    5. Rules of the non-medical treatment of the injuries, first aids.
    6. Injuries of the locomotion apparatus of the trunc – muscles and tendons
    7. Injuries of the locomotion apparatus of the trunc – bones, periost and joints
    8. Injuries of the locomotoin apparatus of the superior extremities – muscles and tendons
    9. Injuries of the locomotoin apparatus of the superior extremities – bones, periost and joints

NAME: Combatives Propaedeutic
TEACHERS: Vít, M. - Novák, J. - Reguli, Z. - Kubíčková, V.
