SYLLABUS: 1. Introduction to preparatory combatives a) characteristic of combatives b) taxonomy of combatives c) function of combatives in school physical education 2. Basic combative techniques a) contact estabilishment b) changing position c) transitions d) hand and arm movements e) leg movements f) lifting, carrying and dropping of a live load (partner) g) falling techniques (principles, psychology, tactics, biomechanics) 3. Basic combatives a) centrifugal (pulls) b) centripedal (pushes) c) opposition (resistence) 4. Combative games as a manner of basic combatives practice Use of equipment in combative games. 5. Basics of combative sports Armwrestling and Tug of war. 6. Use of equipment in combative games 7. Taxonomy of falling technique 8. Physical basis of falling technique 9. Biomechanics of falling technique 10. Basic falling techniques 11. Advanced of falling techniques 12. Falling techniques across barrier with flight phase
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to gain theoretical knowledge on taxonomy, biomechanical structure of preparatory combatives and practical skills, especially falling techniques.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: None
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 1. Theory test: It verifies knowledge of the systematics, biomechanics and history of preparatory battles 2. Practical test: Presentation of min. 8 exercises from preparatory exercises for the development of selected movement skills 3. Practical test: Fitness falling technique test (time limit 2:00 min) 4. Practical test: Advanced fall technique (technique demonstration) 5. Seminar work: Independent development of a stack of 8 exercises with description and video recording
TEACHING_METHODS: Teaching methods: - explanation - demonstration - exercises - drills Self-study: - recommended literature - e-learning - individual exercises
TEACHER_INFO: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/inovace-SEBS-ASEBS/elearning
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: At the end of the course students schould be able to: - understand and explain the combatives taxonomy - define biomechanical structure of preparatory combatives - explain the influence of basic combatives on development of motor abilities - understand and explain principles of creating exercises - understand and explain principles of falling techniques - demonstrate at minimum 8 basic combative exercises for development selected motor ability - show 9 basic falling techniques to all directions - show 3 advanced falling techniques - execute all falling techniques with flight phase - execute falling techniques across adequately high barrier - is physically prepared to apply falling techniques
LITERATURE: http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/padova-technika/

https://www.fsps.muni.cz/inovace-SEBS-ASEBS/elearning/didaktika-karate

NAME: Self-Defence 1
TEACHERS: Bugala, M. - Vít, M. - Kubíčková, V.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_upoly )
SYLLABUS: 1. Definition of self-defence and its place in the taxonomy of combatives 2. Legal aspects of self-defence 3. Preparation and performance in self-defence 4. Principles of self-defence training 5. Psychological preparation in self-defence 6. Strategy and tactics in self-defence 7. Technical means of self-defence 8. Conditioning in self-defence 9. Particularity of self-defence for women 10. Model self-defence situation with all kind of attacks
OBJECTIVES: The course is an introduction to theory and practice of application of combatives - self-defense. Corse is focused on personal defense with using knowledge of cycle of conflict.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: None
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
1. Theoretical test - technical means of self-defense, timing of defense, ladder of use of force
    2. Technical test - overturning a lying opponent, abduction techniques
    3. Conditioning test - tacfit
    4. Exam - theoretical part (according to obligatory literature) - practical part (solving of model self-defence situations according to subject curriculum)
TEACHING_METHODS: Explication, demonstration, exercises, drills. Self-study - recommended literature - e-learning - individual exercises
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: At the end of the course student should be able to: - define self-defence and its place in the taxonomy of combatives - understand the difference between training and performance in combatives sports and self-defence - describe basic self-defence concepts - explain legal limits of self-defence - show basic self-defence techniques according to subject curriculum - understand and apply basic strategical, tactical and technical principles of self-defence - solve basic model self-defence situation
LITERATURE:

NAME: Biology
TEACHERS: Klášterecká, R. - Kopečková, B.
SYLLABUS:
01. Living substance, acellular and cellular organisms, prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, structure of eukaryotic cell.
    02. Cell cycle, genetic information and its expression, cell differentiation.
    03. Tissues, their origin and development. Organs, organ systems.
    04. Epithelial tissue, integumentary system.
    05. Connective tissue, skeletal system.
    06. Muscle tissue, muscular system.
    07. Nervous tissue, nervous system.
    08. Sensory organs.
    09. Body fluids, cardiovascular system.
    10. Endocrine system.
    11. Digestive system.
    12. Urinary system, respiratory system.
    13. Consultations.
OBJECTIVES: Students will acquire basic knowledge of biology with accent on cytology and histology critical to physiotherapeuts. They will be also acquainted with fundamentals of genetics. Students will be able to characterize structure of an animal cell, basic tissues and they will understand the microscopic structure of selected organs in relation to their function.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: oral exam
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: - Students will be able to characterize structure of an animal cell, basic tissues and they will understand the microscopic structure of selected organs in relation to their function.
LITERATURE:
ALBERTS, Bruce. Základy buněčné biologie : úvod do molekulární biologie buňky. Translated by Arnošt Kotyk. 2. vyd. Ústí nad Labem: Espero Publishing, 2004, xxvi, 630. ISBN 8090290620. info

NAME: Kinesiology, Algesiology and Derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 1
TEACHERS: Poulová, L. - Komzák, M. - Poulová, L. - Kotlánová, R. - Kopečková, B.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Osteo-kinematics - physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics of bone and skeletal system.
    02. Cartilage and articular cartilage - physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics.
    03. Dens regular connective tissue - physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics.
    04. Arthro-kinematics - physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics.
    05. Myo-kinematics - physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics.
    06. Rehabilitation Propaedeutics - Introduction to the Field and Integration into Healthcare.
    07. Rehabilitation Propaedeutics - Basic Examination Methods in Rehabilitation and Physiotherapy.
    Practical seminars:
    01. Diagnostic methods in rehabilitation and its relation to Evidence Based Medicine (EBM).
    02. Clinical anamnesis incl. its analysis.
    03. Diagnostics of skin, subdermal tissue and fascias.
    04. Diagnostics of muscles (tonus, trophic state, configuration, strength, length).
    05. Palpatory diagnostics.
    06. Basic anthropometric examination.
    07. Basic examination of axial skeleton range of movement (Thomayer index, Schober index etc.).
    08. Examination of peripheral joint range of movement (goniometry incl. examination of hypermobility).
    09. Aspectual diagnostics of lying, sitting and standing statics.
    10. Aspectual and palpatory diagnostics of dynamic movement patterns incl. gait.
    11. Kinesiology analysis.
OBJECTIVES: The subject introduces students to Kinesiology and Biomechanics of human motor system tissues. The main aim is to understand physiological and pathophysiological mechanisms of adaptation resp. maladaptation of human tissues to different types of stimuli. Acquired knowledge is applied to specific diagnostic and treatment procedures of particular human tissues and motor system as a whole.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: In order to be admitted to the practical exam, it is necessary to meet sufficient attendance and tests scores. - attendance: 100% participation in classes (according to the study and examination regulations, 1 absence is allowed) - 70% point gain from tests (calculated from the score of the best one from the seminar group), in case of failure, credit test (1 attempt), must have min. 80 % score of maximum test points. - after fulfilling the conditions (attendance + tests) admission to the practical exam
TEACHING_METHODS: Students will be exposed to the subject in a form of a lecture that will be followed by practical seminar. These seminars focus on manual techniques of examination and therapy. Students are organized in small groups. Each particular technique is first demonstrated by experienced tutors. Practical training is on peer to peer basis under close supervision of tutors and correction of precise technique.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Successful completion of the subject guarantees student's ability to:
    - understand kinesiology relations
    - understand principles of special examination and therapy techniques.
    - diagnose pathology, select appropriate treatment modality, execute treatment within subject extent
    - students will also be able to educate patients incl. instructions on self-therapy
    - the study of this subject prepares students to clinical activities with patients
LITERATURE:
OATIS, Carol A. Kinesiology : the mechanics and pathomechanics of human movement. Third edition. Philadelphia: Wolters Kluwer, 2017, xix, 1006. ISBN 9781451191561. info
        GROSS, Jeffrey M., Joseph FETTO a Elaine Rosen SUPNICK. Vyšetření pohybového aparátu. Translated by Barbora Homonická Pyšková. 4. vydání. Praha: Stanislav Juhaňák - Triton, 2023, 453 stran. ISBN 9788076841093. info
        KOLÁŘ, Pavel. Rehabilitace v klinické praxi. Druhé vydání. Praha: Galén, 2020, xxxi, 713. ISBN 9788074925009. info
        DYLEVSKÝ, Ivan. Klinická kineziologie a patokineziologie. 1. vydání. Praha: Grada Publishing, 2021, 528 stran. ISBN 9788027102303. info
        ALBERT, Todd J. a Alexander R. VACCARO. Physical examination of the spine. Second edition. New York Stuttgart Delhi Rio de Janeiro: Thieme, 2017. ISBN 978-1-62623-320-1. info

NAME: Swimming sports
TEACHERS: Kodešová, S. - Havrlant, R.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )&& bozp_ok ( bozp_fsps_plav )
SYLLABUS:
01. Swimming fragile health - specifics, forms.
    02. Using different methods of swimming for regeneration.
    03. Modification of swimming modes for individual weakness.
    04. Use of swimming aids.
    05. Modes and load response in the body.
    06. Helped the tired swimmers.
    07. Personal intervention, principles, specific, addressing specific situations, life saving equipment.
    08. Swimming underwater.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is a practical mastery of motor skills aimed at regeneration and rehabilitation of the organism. Activities are aimed both at prevention and the subsequent solution states, related mainly to the weakening of the musculoskeletal system. Students will acquire the skills that are usable for recreational activities and sightseeing activities and moves as their applications in interdisciplinary relationships. The course is the acquisition of skills to deal helped tired swimmers and personal intervention in drowning.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: The basic premise is to demonstrate the skills to deal with the technique of swimming modes in the basic movement patterns, and according to the rules. Swimming skills are assessed in three ways of swimming. It is primarily evaluated swimming triathlon - 100m breaststroke, 100m crawl, 50m backstroke. Another part of the award of credit is an active participation in hours - in the water.
TEACHER_INFO: Povolené jsou 2 neomluvené absence a 1 neaktivní účast ve vodě s náhradním úkolem. Náhrada absence jen po domluvě s vyučujícím.

NAME: Latin, medical terminology
TEACHERS: Prucklová, R. - Vyorálková, J.
SYLLABUS:
01. Úvod do problematiky kurzu, cíle, obsah, výslovnost v latině, přehled latinského gramatického systému, hlavní roviny a směry lidského těla.
    02. Přehled latinských deklinací, 1. deklinace (latinská a řecká substantiva), adjektiva, vybrané předložky, typy zlomenin.
    03. Latinská a řecká substantiva 2. deklinace, adjektiva, klasifikace svalů.
    04. Latinská a řecká substantiva 3.deklinace - souhláskové kmeny, typy ran a poranění.
    05. Latinská a řecká substantiva 3.deklinace - i-kmeny, termíny označující poruchy.
    06. Latinská substantiva 4. a 5. deklinace, termíny pro bolest.
    07. Adjektiva 3. deklinace, nejčastěji užívané zkratky v lékařských zprávách.
    08. Stupňování adjektiv, číslovky, označení kraniálních nervů a obratlů.
    09. Latinské a řecké předpony a přípony, slova odvozená.
    10. Složená slova, názvy fyzioterapeutických technik vycházející z latiny a řečtiny.
    11. Autentické lékařské zprávy – čtení s porozuměním, rozbor.
    12. Opakování.
    13. Zkouškový test.
OBJECTIVES: The course is designed to provide students with practical knowledge of Graeco-Latin medical terminology related mainly to the field of Physical Therapy . Students will gain command of grammatical phenomena and medical terminology necessary for understanding authentic medical reports. They will also master pronunciation of medical terms.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: No prerequisites are applicable.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The course is completed by a written test focused on grammatical phenomena and an oral examination proving the knowledge of medical terminology while analysing authentic medical records.
    Test passmark is 70 %.
    For oral topics see materials to study. Class attendance is compulsory.
TEACHING_METHODS: The course is taught in the form of seminars: reading, writing, speaking, grammar practice. Textbook lessons will be combined with teacher´s handouts. Regular homework will be required.

NAME: English for physiotherapists
TEACHERS: Handlová, Z. - Prucklová, R. - Vyorálková, J.
SYLLABUS:
01. Physiotherapy as a Profession. Phrasal verbs.
    02. Human body and bones. Articles
    03. Muscles and joints. Presentation skills. Presentation Assignment.
    04. Anatomical directions and body movements. Tenses 1.
    05. Resistance exercises. Common injuries and ailments. Tenses 2.
    06. Aerobic exercise. Sports injuries. Tenses 3.
    07. The diagnostic process and examinations. Conditional sentences 1.
    08. Patient management. Risk factors. Modal verbs. 09. Orthopaedic physiotherapy. Conditionals 2.
    09. Neurologic and Geriatric Physiotherapy. Passive.
    10. Vascular and pulmonary disorders. Modal verbs 2.
    11. Pediatric physiotherapy. Gerundium and infinitive after verbs.
    12. Giving feedback and revision.
    13. Final test.
OBJECTIVES: The course is designed to provide students with basic knowledge in physical therapy disciplines,and physiotherapy related topics while successfully mastering reading comprehension and oral as well as written reproduction in English. At the end of the course the students are required to have reached the level B1+ of CEF.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: B1 level of the European Framework for Languages is expected.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: The course is taught in the form of seminars. Students will find topics for each week in the interactive syllabus section ("interaktivní osnova"), and prepare them for the following classes. The items: U3 etc. indicate the number of a unit in the above grammar textbook. The course is completed by an academic presentation on a chosen physiotherapy related topic delivered by each student and by a credit test. After a proper registration, class-attendance becomes compulsory, 2 missed attendances are accepted.
TEACHER_INFO: https://is.muni.cz/auth/el/fsps/podzim2024/bp4810/index.qwarp
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Graduates of this course will acquire basic command of professional terminology in physiotherapy, health, anatomy and various medical and medicine related disciplines. By the end of the course students will be able to effectively deliver presentations in English. In addition, students will gain better command of professionally relevant grammatical phenomena, where the improvement of mainly reproductive communication skills (proper pronunciation, correct spelling, apt use of stylistic registers in written communication and acquisition of basic lexical knowledge) will be emphasized and their eventual mastery expected.

NAME: Physical therapy I
TEACHERS: Toufar, V. - Struhár, I.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. History and parts of Physical therapy. Terms.
    02. General and Special contraindications. General rules for Physical therapy applicaton including security and prescription "lege artis".
    03. Physical therapy effects: Analgesic effect, dispersive effect, muscle-relaxant effect, effect supporting muscle contraction and Anti-edema effect.
    04. General indications including effect and level of disorder.
    05. Direct and indirect effects.
    06. Introduction to mechanotherapy.
    07. Theoretical basic of classical massage: group touches and position among other types of massage
    08. Theoretical basic of sports massage.
    09. Reflexology.
    10. Other types of massage.
    11. Other types of mechanotherapy.
    12. Ultrasound therapy.
    13. Shock wave therapy.
    Practical course:
    01. Work ergonomics. Basic groups of touches.
    02. Massage of lower limbs - posterior part (positioning, individual touches, passive stretching).
    03. Massage of lower limbs - anterior part (positioning, individual touches, passive stretching).
    04. Back massage including scapula area (positioning, individual touches, passive stretching).
    05. Neck massage including scapula area and shoulder girdle massage(positioning, individual touches, passive stretching).
    06. Head massage. Chest massage. Positioning, individual touches, passive stretching.
    07. Massage of upper limbs. Abdominal massage. Positioning, individual touches, passive stretching.
    08. Full body massage.
    09. Preparatory sports massage and therapeutic massage after sport - specifics of individual one.
    10. Stand massage. Massage between performances. Use in practice.
    11. Regenerative massage.
    12. Samples of other massage types and some techniques (hot stones, shietsu etc.).
    13. Individual massage application in practice.
OBJECTIVES: The main goal of this subject is to provide basic knowledge in Physical therapy and its usage in prevention, examination and therapy of musculoskeletal and nervous system influencing all parts of human existence as a part of comprehensive rehabilitation. It´s important to meet a student with general principles of individual physical therapy parts, physiological or patophysiological organism response on their application and with mechanotherapy a their possibilities. The main goal of the practical part is to provide practical skills in mechanotherapy especially focused on practice in classical massage. First it´s important arts superficial and deep palpation. On the other hand it´s important a practical differentiation of each soft tissue level and its examination.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Lectures: pass the final written test
    Practical course: pass the final written test and practical exam.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lectures: frontal type of education with discussion.
    Practical course: focused on the right application of classical massage with correction of qualified physiotherapist or other practitioner.
TEACHER_INFO:
http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/fyzikalni-terapie-1/
    Přístupové jméno: visitor Heslo: p1l0t (pé jedna el nula té) E-learningová podpora výuky předmětu Fyzikální terapie I je pouze doplňujícím materiálem k prezenční formě výuky. Studijní materiál je v souladu se zákonem č. 121/2000 Sb. Autorským zákonem, ve znění pozdějších předpisů, považován za autorské dílo, ke kterému vykonává majetková práva autorská Masarykova univerzita. Upozorňujeme uživatele, že jakékoliv šíření, převzetí či další zpřístupnění jeho obsahu je bez souhlasu MU zakázáno.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
After completing the course the student is able to:
    01. to practice selected massage strokes
    02. to discuss about the selection of selected massage strokes
    03. to assess the current state of the locomotive system
    04. to choose the right massage strokes in relation to the aim of the massage
    05. to practice a sports massage before, in a break of unfinished performance and after the completion of the physical activity
    06. to evaluate the athlete's status based on the subjective feeling before and after the application of the selected type of sports massage

NAME: Pathology
TEACHERS: Lenz, J. - Kopečková, B.
SYLLABUS:
01. Introduction to pathology - the subject of pathology, the application of pathology, basic concepts (1 hour). Termination of the body - death and postmortem changes (1 hour).
    02. Causes of Disease - exogenous (including musculoskeletal injuries) and endogenous causes of disease (2 hours).
    03. Regressive and metabolic changes, progressive changes - necrosis, atrophy and dystrophy, pigments, stones, regeneration, repair, hypertrophy, hyperplasia, metaplasia, dysplasia (2 hours).
    04. Inflammation - a defensive reaction of the organism, local and general symptoms, forms of inflammation (2 hours).
    05. Oncology - cancer, tumor characteristics and division, precanceroses, false tumors, therapy, prevention of bone tumors (2 hours).
    06. Circulatory disorders and pathology of the cardiovascular system (2 hours).
    07. Pathology of the central nervous system pathology and endocrine glands (2 hours).
    08. Musculoskeletal Pathology - skeletal system (2 hours).
    09. Pathology of the musculoskeletal system - muscles (2 hours).
    10. Pathology of the urinary and genital system (2 hours).
    11. Pathology of respiratory system (2 hours).
    12. Pathology of the digestive system (2 hours).
OBJECTIVES: The aim is to introduce the teaching of pathology concepts with expert human pathology and understanding the basic general pathological processes of the human body, that causes disease, including the reactions of the organism compensatory mechanisms and forms of healing. In other classes students will be familiar with the pathological processes in various organ systems emphasizing the pathology of the motor system.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Successful completion of the final written test (min. 80%).
TEACHING_METHODS: Frontal type of education with discussion.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Students will be able to:
    - describe the basic areas of pathology that are related to the understanding of related clinical issues and medical-rehabilitation treatment in individual fields of medicine and medical rehabilitation.
LITERATURE:
GOODMAN, Catherine Cavallaro a Kenda FULLER. Pathology : implications for the physical therapist. Fourth edition. St. Louis, Mo.: Elsevier, 2015, xviii, 178. ISBN 9781455745913. info
        MAČÁK, Jirka. Patologie. Praha: GRADA, 2004, 347 s. ISBN 80-247-0785-3. info

NAME: Physical therapy II
TEACHERS: Struhár, I. - Toufar, V. - Struhár, I.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4812 && bp4803 && bp4808 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Reflexology and its effects, physiological base.
    02. Introduction into phototherapy: - definition, general principles, therapeutical effects, methodology applications, contra/indications.
    03. Phototherapy:
    - UVA, UVB, UVC;
    - IRA, IRB, IRC;
    - Polarized light (biolamp)
    - Polarized light (laser)
    04. Electrotherapy:
    Dividing of electrotherapy. General principles.
    Electrodes and their wraps, ways of application, intensity.
    Relationship between the type of current, the effect and intensity.
    Galvanic current (current density) and its application.
    Four-chamber bath with application of galvanic current.
    Alternating and pulsed currents, terms.
    Low-frequency currents – Leduc´s, Farad´s, Neofarad´s.
    H-waves
    Träbert´s currents

    Practical course:
    01. Segment technque. Search reflective changes (apsection, palpation). - Touches: Pusched spiral, with two thumbs, among processi spinosi. Touches: Saw touch, sliding vibration, intermitent pull down. Edges shoulder-blade massage. M. trapezius massage. Under the shoulder-blade massage. Intercostal muscles massage. M. supraspinatus and infraspinatus massage. Vibration of the whole back. Trapezoidal touch. Neck muscles massage. Linea nuchae terminalis massage. Forehead massage. Cranial arch massage. Swab from the brow ridges to shoulder girdle.
    02. Search back reflective changes. Reflexology of the back - group A.
    03. Search back reflective changes. Reflexology of the back - group B.
    04. Search head and neck reflective changes. Reflexology of the head and neck - group A.
    05. Search head and neck reflective changes. Reflexology of the head and neck - group B.
    06. Search thoracic reflective changes. Reflexology of the thorax.
    07. Search pelvic reflective changes. Reflexology of the pelvis.
OBJECTIVES: The main goal of this course is to provide basic knowledge in Physical therapy and its usage in prevention, examination and therapy of musculoskeletal and nervous system influencing all parts of human existence as a part of comprehensive rehabilitation. It´s important to meet a student with general principles of individual physical therapy parts, physiological or patophysiological organism response on their application and with possibilities of phototherapy and electrotherapy.The main goal of practical course is to provide practical skills in mechanotherapy especially focused on practice in reflexology.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Lectures:
    1. Pass the final written test.
    Practical course:
    1. pass the final written test and discussion of topics discussed during two previous terms.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lectures: frontal type of education with discussion.
    Practical course: focused on the right application of classical massage with correction of qualified physiotherapist or other practitioner.

NAME: Propedeutics in rehabilitation and basics of physiotherapy II
TEACHERS: Poulová, L. - Vysoký, R. - Horák, V. - Ševčíková, B.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4806 && bp4808 && bp4812 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Introduction to neurorehabilitation incl. Ontogenetic aspects of motor learning.
    02. Introduction to respiratory physiotherapy.
    03. Introduction to sensomotor exercises (Freeman, Janda, Vávrová; Propriofoot, Bosu, Overball, Powerball, Posturomed…).
    04. Introduction to dermatoneuromuscular therapy according to Kenna, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF).
    05. Introduction to Vojta's Method.
    06. Introduction K   Method Brügger, Brunkow, Brunnström, Klapp.
    07. Introduction to dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS according to Kolář).
    08. Introduction to Bobath concept (NDT).
    09. Introduction to Feldenkreis method, biofeedback.
    10.
    11. Introduction to basal stimulation methodology.
    12. Introduction to craniosacral therapy.
    13. Introduction to Maitland concept.
    14. School of back.
    15. Introduction to McKenzie therapy (MDT).
    16. Introduction to the concept of "Spiraldynamic", SM system.
    17. Basics of balneology - species and use of natural healing resources in rehabilitation. Indication groups and legislation associated with the topic of natural healing resources (spa law).
    18. Basics of ergonomics - evaluation of working conditions - physical, chemical, biological factors. environment.
    Exercises:
    01. Physiotherapy in   Preventive care.
    02. Physiotherapy in acute care.
    03. Physiotherapy in chronic diseases.
    04. Physiotherapy and Sport Handicapped.
    05. Respiratory physiotherapy.
    06. Basics of Ergonomics of Work, Principles of Health Protection Measures - Practical Application to Physiotherapy (eg Back School)
    07. Relaxation techniques (Jacobson, Schultz, Respiratory and Yoga techniques).
    08. Kinesiotherapy based on   ontogenetic development.
    09.
    10. Sensomotor exercises.
OBJECTIVES: The aim is to understand the nature of physiotherapy as a specific preventive and therapeutic methods, to understand differentiation of movements, the ability to apply physiotherapy procedures of selected diagnoses. Students will acquire medical information about physical education in surgery, ICU, ARO and burns, as well as obtain information on physiotherapy practice after abdominal and thoracic operations and amputations of the upper and lower limbs, also become familiar with the procedures of the breast after ablation.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: bp4806 Propedeutics in rehabilitation and basics of physiotherapy I
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Lectures: Regular participation in teaching (maximum 2 absence).
    Exercise: Proof of practical skills and successful elaboration of written tests (fulfillment at 80 %) in the course and at the end of the semester is a condition for admission to the oral test.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lecture: frontal type of education with discussion.
    Seminars: practical exercises in a small group of students.

NAME: Physiology
TEACHERS: Babula, P. - Dobrovolná, J. - Kučera, J.
SYLLABUS: Introduction to Physiology Basic concepts and principles Organization of the human body Cell Physiology Cell membrane and transport mechanisms Energy metabolism and cellular respiration Cell ontogenesis Tumor transformation Muscle Physiology Structure and types of muscle tissue Microscopic structure of skeletal muscles Energy metabolism in muscles Mechanics of muscle contraction Skeletal muscle remodeling Adaptation to physical activity Physiology of Bones and Joints Structure and function of bones Types of bone tissue, types of joints, microscopic and macroscopic structure Physiology of bone remodeling Physiology of joint movements and remodeling Joint stabilization Nervous System Physiology Structure and function of nerve cells Electrical properties, membrane potential, action potential, myelination Central and peripheral nervous system Neurotransmission and synaptic communication Sensory and motor pathways Autonomic nervous system Cardiovascular System Structure and basic function of the heart and circulatory system The heart as a pump Electrical activity of the heart, electrocardiogram Mechanics of heart contraction, cardiac cycle Cardiac output Myocardial remodeling Hemodynamics and Blood Pressure Basic principles of hemodynamics Blood pressure regulation Vascular system and its role in hemodynamics Microcirculation Physiology of hemostasis Respiratory System Anatomy and physiology of the respiratory system Mechanics of breathing Gas transport and breathing regulation Digestive System Processes of digestion and nutrient absorption Regulation of the digestive system Excretory Physiology Structure and function of the kidneys and urinary system Renal blood circulation, urine formation, and composition Role of the kidneys in regulating body fluid volume and composition Hormones affecting kidney function Regulation of Fluids and Electrolytes, Volume, and Tonicity Mechanisms of maintaining internal environment stability Water and electrolyte balance Mechanisms of volume and osmolality regulation
OBJECTIVES: The Physiology course provides students with a comprehensive understanding of fundamental physiological principles and mechanisms that govern the functioning of the human body. Students will explore the organization of the human organism at the cellular, tissue, organ, and system levels, gaining deeper insight into key physiological processes. The course covers cellular physiology, including transport mechanisms and energy metabolism, and gradually expands knowledge on the physiology of muscle tissue, bones and joints, the nervous system, the cardiovascular system, hemodynamics, blood pressure regulation, as well as the respiratory, digestive, and excretory systems. Emphasis is placed on the interconnection of these systems and their regulatory mechanisms, which ensure homeostasis and adaptation to various conditions. The aim of the course is not only to provide theoretical knowledge but also to foster critical thinking and the ability to apply acquired knowledge in practical situations.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Successfully completed a test with control issues in the curriculum.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES: Upon completing the Physiology course, the student will be able to: Understand the fundamental functions of the human body as a whole and recognize how individual organs and systems interact to maintain homeostasis. Apply theoretical knowledge in practice through active participation in assignments, drills, tests, program essays, and independent completion of worksheets. Analyze the impact of external factors on the human body's functions, including the effects of physical exertion, disease, stress, and other influences on individual organs and overall bodily function. Identify physiological differences across various life stages, from childhood to adulthood and old age. Utilize acquired knowledge in further studies at FSpS, where it will be essential for understanding related subjects. Prepare for future studies and professional practice, where an understanding of physiological processes will enable more effective application of knowledge in fields such as sports science, rehabilitation, healthcare, and human movement research.
LITERATURE:
WARD, Jeremy P. T. a R. W. A. LINDEN. Základy fyziologie. První české vydání. Praha: Galén, 2010, 164 stran. ISBN 9788072626670. info

NAME: Kinesiology, Algesiology and Derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 2
TEACHERS: Bazalová, P. - Komzák, M. - Bazalová, P. - Poulová, L.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4808 && bp4803 && bp4806 && bp4812 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. General principles of human motor control.
    02. Cortical level of motor control incl. neuro-facilitation and inhibition methods.
    03. Subcortical level of motor control incl. neuro-facilitation and inhibition methods.
    04. Spinal level of motor control incl. neuro-facilitation and inhibition methods.
    05. Methodology of muscle strength development.
    06. Definition, physiology and pathophysiology of pain.
    07. Classification and differential diagnostics of pain.
    08. Invasive and non-invasive means of pain management.
    09. Non-invasive and non-pharmacological means of causal pain management in particular pain types.
    10. Non-invasive and non-pharmacological means of symptomatic pain management in particular pain types.
    11. Psychological and social aspects of pain.
    Practical seminars:
    01. Principles of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation incl. diagnostics of muscle tonus, strength and trophic condition.
    02. Methodology of muscle strength development.
    03. Anamnesis in neurology, mental state examination, speech examination, examination of gnostic functions (sight, hearing, tactile sensation, somatognosis incl. neglect syndrome)
    04. Reflexology (physiology, pathophysiology).
    05. Examination of coordination and balance.
    06. Examination of abnormal movement.
    07. Examination of cranial nerves I - XII.
    08. Radicular syndromes in lower and upper extremities.
    09. Diagnostics and therapy of pain.
OBJECTIVES: The subject is based on previous study of Kinesiology, Algesiology and derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 1 and further focuses on diagnostics and therapy of muscle tonus and strength and neuro-diagnostics including pain. Therapeutic interventions cover principles of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation as well as methods for muscle strength training in sports. causal relations and general principles of kinesiology. The main aim of the subject is understanding of causal relation and general principles of kinesiology. Acquired knowledge is applied to specific diagnostic and treatment techniques in the field of physiotherapy.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS:
Kinesiology, Algesiology and derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 1
    Propedeutics in Rehabilitation and Basics of Physiotherapy 1
    Anatomy 1
ASSESMENT_METHODS: In order to be admitted to the practical exam, it is necessary to meet sufficient attendance and tests scores. - attendance: 100% participation in classes (according to the study and examination regulations, 1 absence is allowed) - 70% point gain from tests (calculated from the score of the best one from the seminar group), in case of failure, credit test (1 attempt), must have min. 80 % score of maximum test points. - after fulfilling the conditions (attendance + tests) admission to the practical exam
TEACHING_METHODS: Students will be exposed to the subject in a form of a lecture that will be followed by practical seminar. These seminars focus on manual techniques of examination and therapy. Students are organized in small groups. Each particular technique is first demonstrated by experienced tutors. Practical training is on peer to peer basis under close supervision of tutors and correction of precise technique.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Successful completion of the subject guarantees student's ability to:
    - understand kinesiology relations
    - understand principles of special examination and therapy techniques.
    - diagnose pathology, select appropriate treatment modality, execute treatment within subject extent
    - students will also be able to educate patients incl. instructions on self-therapy
    - the study of this subject prepares students to clinical activities with patients
LITERATURE:

NAME: Biomechanics
TEACHERS: Kalichová, M. - Jemelková, M. - Kalichová, M.
SYLLABUS:
01. Definition of biomechanics, importace, history.
    02. Physical base of biomechanics:
    - line coordinates, scalares, vectores, units.
    03. Kinematics: mass point, distance, velocity, acceleration, straight motion, accelerated motion, cirgular motion, motions in field of gravity of Earth, describing motion with graphs.
    04. Dynamics: force, Newton's Laws, effects of force, deformations, Hook's Law, momentum and its conservation, impulse, centripetal force, inertial force, D'Alambert's Principle.
    05. Mechanics of rigid body: moment of force, principle of moments, centre of gravity, equilibrium positions, statics, frictional force, air resistance force, inclined plane, lever systems.
    06. Mechanical energy, work, power, conservation of energy. Biological base of biomechanics:
    - The geometry of the human body (anatomical planes and directions, body segments, kinematic chain, weight and center of gravity segments, center of gravity, moment of inertia segments).
    07. Rheology (rheological models).
    08. The mechanical properties of biomaterials (stiffness, elasticity, hardness, relaxation and creep, fatigue).
    09. The mechanical properties of bone tissue (bone stress and deformation, elastic and plastic deformation, bone remodeling).
    10. The mechanical properties of cartilage, tendons and ligaments (cartilage lubrication, hysteresis elastic fibers, the relationship between stress and strain, tissue viscoelasticity).
    11. The mechanical properties of skeletal muscles (mechanical properties, gradation of muscle tension, Hill model, the dependence on the parameters of muscle force of muscular contraction).
    12. Biomechanics of control subsystems (generation and spread impulses, load of nerve tissue).
    13. Biomechanics motion segments (mechanical triad, decomposition muscle force, muscle moment of force, lever principle of movement in the joints, types of levers in the human body, model examples).


    Practical course:
    They correlate and follow the course of lectures.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the subject is to explain the mechanical structure and mechanical behavior of the human musculosceletal system, especially in sport movement, and in this approach the research methods, based on which the human body can be analyzed.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Lectures: oral exam
    Exercise: presentation
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lectures: theoretical presentations.
    Practical course: applications on exercises.
LITERATURE:
KALICHOVÁ, Miriam, Josef BALÁŽ, Petr BEDŘICH a Martin ZVONAŘ. Základy biomechaniky tělesných cvičení. 1. vyd. Brno: Masarykova univerzita, 2011, 193 s. ISBN 978-80-210-5551-3. info
        JANURA, Miroslav. Úvod do biomechaniky pohybového systému člověka. 1. vyd. Olomouc: Univerzita Palackého, 2003, 84 s. ISBN 8024406446. info

NAME: Biophysics
TEACHERS: Harabiš, V. - Kolářová, J. - Kopečková, B.
SYLLABUS:
1. Effects of mechanical forces and acoustic fields on living systems.
    2. Biological effects of electromagnetic fields and non-ionising radiation.
    3. Conventional X-ray imaging methods.
    4. Modern tomographic methods (CT, MRI).
    5. Diagnostic methods using radionuclides.
    6. Methods and devices for radiotherapy.
    7. Electrodiagnostic methods.
    8. Ultrasound imaging, Doppler and combined methods.
    9. Methods and devicas for physical therapy.
    10. Biophysics of cardiovascular system.
    11. Biophysics of sensory organs.
OBJECTIVES: The principles of devices used in medicine with special emphasis on the area of physical therapy; identify possible risks which are connected with the use of some medical devices (with mechanical, electromagnetic or light character, ioniising radiation); define principles of safe use of these devices both for patients and for medical staff; understand physical principles of some physiological processes.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Lectures: Colloquium on pre-defined set of questions.
LITERATURE:
GLASER, Roland. Biophysics : an introduction. 2nd ed. Heidelberg: Springer, 2012, xx, 407. ISBN 9783642252112. info
        HRAZDIRA, Ivo, Vojtěch MORNSTEIN a Jiřina ŠKORPÍKOVÁ. Základy biofyziky a zdravotnické techniky. 1. vydání. Brno: Neptun, 2006, 312 stran. ISBN 8086850013. info

NAME: Pharmacology
TEACHERS: Tomášková, I.
SYLLABUS:
GENERAL PHARMACOLOGY:
    01. Basic concepts, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, dosing and specific treatments for children and old people.
    02. Methods of drug administration, absorption, metabolism, excretion of drugs.
    03. The emergence of new drugs, generics, leaflet, informing the patient.
    01. Dosage forms, ointments, tablets, solutions, patches ..., advantages and disadvantages of each drug. forms absorption, indications.

    DISEASE:
    01. The division generally.
    02. Inflammation, arthritis, gout, cramps, osteoporosis, and the principle mechanism of action of drugs.
    SPECIAL PHARMACOLOGY

    01. Distribution of drugs, a brief overview of all groups.
    02. Pharmacology musculoskeletal diseases (in detail):
    03. Total NSA, NSA local, coxiby and new medicines, disease-modifying drugs, corticosteroids.
    04. Treatment days chondroprotektiva and nutritional supplements.
OBJECTIVES: Teaching this course is to provide students focus on a sufficient level to prevent and treatment of diseases, the general issue of drug treatment and a deeper knowledge of the musculoskeletal system in the range proportionate to the field.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Pass a written test min. 70% complete with a number of questions.
TEACHING_METHODS: Frontal type of education with discussion.

NAME: Clinical physiology and pathophysiology
TEACHERS: Kapounková, K. - Grün, V.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4813 && bp4819 && bp4818 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Syllabus of lectures:
    01. Characteristics of sport disciplines (type of load, duration of performance, load intensity). Sports Performance Factors.
    02. Physiological principles of training.
    03. Effect of genetics on performance. determinants of sport performance.
    04. Stress response (control systems). Disturbance of homeostasis. Acidobasic equilibrium - stress acidosis. Response of the organism to different types of body load.
    05. Metabolic performance characteristics (metabolic cover, energy sources, energy supply).
    06. Functional Performance Characteristics (HR, VO2, LA, ..).
    07. Characteristics of the athlete (load test to maximum: HR max, VO2 max, Wingate test: P max, AC, fatigue index, somatic characteristics).
    08. Adaptation process. Regulation of adaptation processes. Adaptation mechanisms.
    09. Specific adaptations of the organism to the burden (speed, force, endurance, force endurance, speed-force, coordinating aesthetic, combat, sports games).
    10. Physiological differences during stress response and adaptation in relation to ontogenesis.
    11. Influence of the environment on performance (cold, heat, pressure). Acclimatization.
    12. Desecration process. Detrain.
    13. Specifics of female response (menstrual cycle, pregnancy, childbirth, puerperium).

    Syllabus of exercises:
    01. Introduction to exercise Physiology of the load, characteristics of sport
    02. Sports performance factors
    03. Metabolic performance characteristics
    04. Performance characteristics during exercise
    05. Specific adaptations of the organism to the load
    06. Stress tests - introduction, performance characteristics of the athlete
    07. Determination of thresholds (ventilation, lactate, circulating), Conconi test
    08. Spiroergometry
    09. PWC170
    10. Selected tests of anaerobic assumptions (Jump ergometry, Wingate test)
    11. Somatic characteristics of an athlete
    12. Somatotype detection
    13. Physiological essence of training, Health risks
    14. Delivery of logs and worksheets
OBJECTIVES: Main objectives can be summarized as follows: the basic knowledge about physiology; to understand the physiologic process of organism in the course sports activity; the types of the sports activity
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Attending of subject is obligatory. During term student fill in worksheets. The whole subject is finished by oral examination.
LITERATURE:

NAME: Neurology
TEACHERS: Bakošová, L. - Joppeková, Ľ. - Kapounková, K. - Kočica, J. - Krkoška, P. - Kokošová, V.

SYLLABUS:
01. Introduction, concept and content of neurology.

    04. Syndrome I and II. Motoneuron.
    05. Extrapyramidal syndrome.
    06. Cerebellar syndrome.
    07. Meningeal syndrome and the syndrome of intracranial hypertension.

    09. Stem syndromes.
    10. Subcortical syndromes.
    11. Cortical syndromes.
    12. Phatic functions and their disorders.

OBJECTIVES: In this course students have the opportunity to gain theoretical and practical knowledge about neural activity system, the basic neurological syndromes and neurological examination structure.

NAME: Physical therapy III
TEACHERS: Toufar, V. - Srnec, J. - Dobrovolná, J. - Kopečková, B.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4818 && bp4819 && bp4824 && bp4816 && bp4820 && bp4822 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Low-frequency current - Diadynamic current.
    02. TENS and its division.
    03. TENS with neuromodulation effect and its division.
    04. Other types of TENS.
    05. Alternating and simultaneous stimulation according to Hufschmidt and Jantsche.
    06. Medium-frequency current - classical interference current.
    07. Medium-frequency current - isoplanar and dipole vector field.
    08. Contactless electrotherapy – low-frequency.
    09. Distance electrotherapy.
    10. Magnetotherapy.
    11. High-frequency current – diathermy therapy.
    12. Shortwave diathermy.
    13. High-frequency current – ultrashortwave and microwave diathermy.

    Practical course:
    01. Mechanotherapy – manual traction (of shoulder and pelvic girdle, lumbar spine), mechanical traction, couch for autotraction, vacuum compression therapy and ultrasound treatment.
    02. Thermotherapy - heat medium different types application.
    03. Phototherapy - low level laser therapy, biostimul color therapy, AVS.
    04. Electrotherapy - security, principles, an individual positioning, intensity, time and frequency of procedures. Focused placement of electrodes on different body parts (skin, subcutaneus tissue, fascia, muscles, joints, ligaments,...). Electrode polarity, quality and wraps.
    05. Application of galvanic current and iontophoresis (principles - protective solutions x layered electrodes, effects, an individual positioning, current density, intensity, time and frequency of procedures). Four-chamber bath with galvanic current (principles, an individual positioning, current density, intensity, time and frequency of procedures).
    06. Diadynamic current: general effects, therapeutical effects, methods of applications and indications/contraindications.
    07. Träbert´s current – placement of electrods and their polarity focused on the required effect, Farad´s, Neofarad´s, Leduc´s current (security, effects, an individual positioning, current density, intensity, time and frequency of procedures).
    08. Medium-Frequency current – Classical Interferential current.
    09. TENS treatment (traditional, acupuncture, hyperstimulation mode). Importance of CV mode. Principles, effects, an individual positioning, current density, intensity, time and frequency of procedures.
    10. An individual Physical therapy procedures revision.
OBJECTIVES:
The main goal of this course is to provide basic knowledge in Physical therapy and its usage in prevention, examination and therapy of musculoskeletal and nervous system influencing all parts of human existence as a part of comprehensive rehabilitation.
    It´s important to meet a student with general principles of individual physical therapy parts, physiological or patophysiological organism response on their application and with possibilities of electrotherapy.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Physical therapy II, Physical therapy in practice II, Anatomy II
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Lectures: pass the final written test. (min 70 %)
    Practical course: focused on the right application of physical therapy procedures with correction of qualified physiotherapist or other practitioner.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lectures: frontal type of education with discussion
    Practical course: focused on the right application of thermotherapy, hydrotherapy, electrotherapy and phototherapy with correction of qualified physiotherapist or other practitioner.

NAME: Sports Medicine
TEACHERS: Komzák, M.
SYLLABUS:
01. Introduction, branche of sports medicine, information sources.
    02. Cardiovascular questions in sport, risk of cardiac complication and sudden death in sport. Stress ECG.
    03. Prevention of sports injuries (acute injuries, injuries of overstress, insufficiency od respiratory, circulatory systems and metabolism). Preventive medical examens.
    04. Physical activity and health - optimal movement regimen. Risks of hypokinesy (civilizational disorders) and overloading.
    05. Helath backup of sport trainings and competitions, and other exercises. Role of medical officer. Prevention and solution of health problems.
    06. Health risks during sport and exercise in children, seniors and women.
    07. Diabetes mellitus adn sport. Migraine and sport.
    08. Asthma bronchiale and sport.
    09. Health risks of doping in sport.
OBJECTIVES:
At the end of the course students should be able to know:
    - relationships between health and physical activity
    - determine the limits of physical activity for the purpose of the individual

NAME: Basics of philosophy and ethics in rehabilitation
TEACHERS: Hurych, E. - Moudr, V. - Palka, J.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Myth and Philosophy, Classical Greek philosophy, Hellenism.
    02. Medieval thinking, the Renaissance, the Modern Period, the Enlightenment.
    03. Modern thinking; postmodern thinking.
    04. Ethics, morality, metaethics, normative ethics, environmental ethics.
    05. The principles of medical ethics and bioethics: respect for autonomy, the principle of non-harming, the principle of well-doing, a question of justice.
    06. Ethical problems related to the beginning of life
    07. Death and dying, relationship to the dying, attitude to death, definition of death.
    08. Euthanasia and assisted suicide.
    09. Rights of the sick. The philosophical problem of liberty and its ethical consequences.
    10. Ethics of Medical Research - History, Nuremberg Code, Helsinki Declaration,
    11. Ethics and pediatrics - prenatal period, newborn, communicable child, adolescent, family contact, hospital and children, hospitalized child rights charter, disabled child.
    12. Physiotherapist's Code of Ethics (WCPT, UNIFY).
    13. Summary.

    Seminars:
    01. The ethical approaches in the context of deontological, consequentialistic ethics, and the ethics of virtues.
    02. The analysis of the selected ethical dilemmas (of a kind of „Draisine“, or „Captain“).
    03. Discussion on the selected ethical dilemma.
    04. The epidemiological situation and its ethical aspects.
    05. The role of ethics committees, ethics committee at the Ministry of Health of the Czech Republic, attempts by the Council of Europe to unify basic ethical practices.
    06. The ethical problems of assisted reproduction.
    07. The hospice movement, respect for the dead body, ethical issues of transplantation, and organ donation from dead donors. Palliative care.
    08. Not extending life at any cost - the moral difference between actively killing a patient and letting the patient die.
    09. Discussion of individual rights. Medical secrets, informed consent. Right to refuse treatment.
    10. Informed Consent, Unethical Experiments Today, Animal Experiments.
    11. Ethics and genetics, ethics, and oncology. The truth about the diagnosis, the stages of accepting this fact.
    12. Analysis of the Physiotherapist's Code of Ethics (WCPT, UNIFY).
    13. Final discussion.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the subject is to provide an overview on historical investigation of the basic ethical problems in a broad philosophical context (ontology, epistemology, logic, and aesthetics). The other aim is to educate students in the basic ethical topics in the field of health care. Finally, to prove how students manage the required knowledge, attitudes, and skills.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Presentation of the selected topic and conduct of the discussion. 80 % participation in seminars. Written test. 55 % correct from 20 questions. Essay - evaluation of oral output according to given structure. Oral interview - group colloquium.
TEACHING_METHODS: Theoretical training through lectures and self-study; seminars on the selected ethical topic in the field of health care.
LITERATURE:
STÖRIG, Hans Joachim. Malé dějiny filozofie. Edited by Petr Rezek, Translated by Miroslav Petříček - Karel Šprunk. 5. vyd. Praha: Zvon, 1996, 559 s. ISBN 807113175X. info

NAME: Kinesiology, Algesiology and Derived Techniques of Diagnosis and Therapy 3
TEACHERS: Komzák, M. - Bartošová, S. - Bartošová, S. - Zigo, J. - Kopečková, B. - Vysoký, R.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4819 && bp4818 && bp4816 && bp4820 && bp4822 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Kinesiology of hand and wrist - function, joints, arches, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    Kinesiology of arm, forearm and elbow - function, joints, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    Kinesiology of shoulder - function, joints, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    Kinesiology of upper extremity from the global motor patterns point of view.
    Practical seminars:
    Visual and tactile diagnostics of dermis. Barrier treatment in dermis within segmental reflexology incl. viscerocutaneous reflexes.
    Diagnostics and therapy of fascia incl. its role in functional pathology chains.
    Visual and tactile diagnostics of muscle tonus, strength, trophic. Special attention is paid to muscle testing according to V. Janda and muscle topography. Manual therapy of particular muscles incl. techniques of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation/inhibition.
    Diagnostics and therapy of periosteum points.
    Diagnostics of joints - active and passive range of motion, capsular patterns, joint play. Therapy of joints – manipulative and stabilization techniques, orthotics, taping.
    Application of above listed techniques of diagnostics and therapy to hand region incl. hand arches, wrist, elbow and shoulder girdle.
OBJECTIVES: The subject is based on previous study of Kinesiology, Algesiology and derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 2 and further focuses on upper extremities. The main aim is to apprehend local kinesiology relations at the level of upper limb as well as global relations between trunk kinesiology and lower/upper limbs. Acquired knowledge is applied to understand underlying principles of examination and treatment techniques in the field of physiotherapy. The subject deals in detail with passive and active factors of stability of upper extremity motor segments. It gives causal definition of functional as well as structural physiology and pathology.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Kinesiology, Algesiology and derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 2
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 100% presence at practical seminars, 70% mark acquisition from through-term tasks, 70% mark acquisition from through-term written tests and practical exams. Final written exam (minimum of 70% successful rate) and practical exam in front of the examination board of 3 examiners. The student is not qualified for final exam in case of not fulfilling the percentage of through-term tasks, through-term written tests and practical exams. Final written test and final practical exam contributes to 50 and 50% of final evaluation respectively (A-F).
TEACHING_METHODS: Students will be exposed to the subject in a form of a lecture that will be followed by practical seminar. These seminars focus on manual techniques of examination and therapy. Students are organized in small groups. Each particular technique is first demonstrated by experienced tutors. Practical training is on peer to peer basis under close supervision of tutors and correction of precise technique.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Successful completion of the subject guarantees student's ability to:
    - understand kinesiology relations within trunk region.
    - understand principles of special examination and therapy techniques.
    - diagnose pathology, select appropriate treatment modality, execute treatment within subject extent.
    - students will also be able to educate patients incl. instructions on self-therapy.
    - the study of this subject prepares students to clinical activities with patients.
LITERATURE:
Janda, V. et al. Svalové funkční testy. Vyd. 1. Praha: Grada, 2004. 328 s. ISBN 9788024707228

NAME: Pedagogy and psychology

01. Help and social control. Types of help.
    02. Effective communication, assertiveness.
    03. Advice, procedures, diagnostic problems. Classical clinical approach, humanistic approach.
    04. Relationship with the client, directivity in communication with the client.
    05. Communication with clients and patients of different ages.

Students will be given the opportunity to verify practically their ability to establish contact, provide social support, question and develop these skills in peer exercises.

NAME: Clinical Physiology and Pathophysiology II
TEACHERS: Dobrovolná, J. - Kučera, J. - Kučera, J.
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Basic concepts in pathophysiology: health, disease, factors of disease. External factors of disease. Genetic determinants of disease.
    02. Pathogenesis of atherosclerosis, clinical complications of atherosclerosis.
    03. Inflammation and healing.
    04. Pathophysiologically significant metabolic disorders.
    05. Selected chapters on the pathophysiology of the endocrine system.
    06. Selected chapters on pathophysiology of the cardiovascular system.
    07. Selected chapters in pathophysiology of the nervous system (CNS diseases, PNS).
    08. Disorders of acid-base balance.
    09. Pain.
    10. Selected chapters in the pathophysiology of the respiratory system.
    11. Pathophysiology of connective tissue and muscles.
    12. Disorders of the immune system.
    Seminars follow the thematic course of lectures
OBJECTIVES: In the field of physiotherapy, knowledge of reaction and adaptation to physical stress is a key area of ​​a comprehensive treatment procedure. The aim of the course is to present information from physiology and pathophysiology of movement load. The subject deals with physiological and pathophysiological processes of reaction and adaptation of selected functional and organ systems to movement load, load limits, movement activity prescription and resulting effect in positive and negative sense.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Anatomy, Physiology,
ASSESMENT_METHODS: Oral examination

NAME: Physiotherapy in clinical disciplines 3
TEACHERS: Vysoký, R. - Toufar, V. - Kubina, S. - Belás, J. - Siegel, V.
SYLLABUS:
01. Introduction to rehabilitation in internal medicine. Rational choice arguments rehabilitation strategies in internal medicine in connection with the removal of physical history, assessment of functional status of the patient by physiotherapist. General indications and contraindications for rehabilitation in internal medicine.
    02. Introduction to cardiac rehabilitation patients. Interpretation of assessment of blood pressure, heart rate, subjective and objective responses in relation to the patient's physical activity. Physiological and pathological reactions to stress the circulatory system.
    03. I. cardiovascular rehabilitation phase - hospitalization. Rehabilitation strategy after uncomplicated myocardial infarction after myocardial infarction with complications, recommend suitable physical activities and the principles of secondary prevention after hospital discharge.
    04. II. cardiovascular rehabilitation phase - early posthospitalization. Structure of outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program directed at patients after myocardial infarction after aorto-coronary bypass, valve surgery, heart failure. Indications and contraindications for exercise. Determination of training intensity. Frequency and duration of training. Methods of load.
    05. The effect of physical activity on risk factors for CAD. The physiological effects of regular training in CAD. Aerobic capacity in patients with coronary artery disease. Prescription of physical activity in patients with cardiovascular disease.
    06. Rehabilitation strategies in patients with chronic heart failure hospitalization and posthospitalisation phase.
    07. Rehabilitation strategies in cardiosurgery.
    08. Rehabilitation strategies in patients after acute pulmonary embolism.
    09. Rehabilitation strategies in patients with peripheral arterial disease and venous system of lower limbs.
    10. Rehabilitation strategies in hypertensive, diabetic, individuals with obesity.
    11. Rehabilitation strategies in patients with pulmonary disease.
    12. Strategies in geriatric rehabilitation patients and long recumbent patients with internal diseases.
    13. Rehabilitation strategies in rehabilitation of patients with rheumatic disease.
OBJECTIVES: The course is a comprehensive view on the issue of therapeutic and strategies of rehabilitation and methodologies physiotherapy/kinesiotherapy in internal medicine with a focus on detailed problem patients with cardiovascular disease. After successfully completing the course the student will be able to confront the results and procedures in kinesiotherapy the overall team care for patients with cardiology and other internal diseases.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Requirements for successful completion:
    1. Compulsory attendance at lectures.
    2. Successful completion of written tests.
    3. Successful presentation of short presentation (5-10 minutes) on a selected topic related to lectured problems.
    4. Successful completion of the oral examination.
TEACHER_INFO:
http://www.fsps.muni.cz/impact/aplikovana-fyzioterapie-2/

NAME: Kinesiology, Algesiology and Derived Techniques of Diagnosis and Therapy 3
TEACHERS: Bartošová, S. - Komzák, M. - Ševčíková, B. - Pliska, P. - Zigo, J. - Kopečková, B.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4833 && bp4830 && bp4829 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Kinesiology of foot – function, joints, arches, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    02. Kinesiology of knee joint – function, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    03. Kinesiology of hip joint - function, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    04. Kinesiology of pelvic girdle - function, passive and active stability of particular motor segments, clinical aspects, functional and structural pathology of this region.
    05. Kinesiology of lower extremity from the global motor patterns point of view.

    Practical seminars:
    01. Visual and tactile diagnostics of dermis. Barrier treatment in dermis within segmental reflexology incl. viscerocutaneous reflexes.
    02. Diagnostics and therapy of fascia incl. its role in functional pathology chains.
    03. Visual and tactile diagnostics of muscle tonus, strength, trophic. Special attention is paid to muscle testing according to V. Janda and muscle topography. Manual therapy of particular muscles incl. techniques of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation/inhibition.
    04. Diagnostics and therapy of periosteum points.
    05. Diagnostics of joints - active and passive range of motion, capsular patterns, joint play. Therapy of joints – manipulative and stabilization techniques, orthotics, taping.
    06. Application of above listed techniques of diagnostics and therapy to foot region incl. foot arches, talocrural joint, knee joint, hip joint and pelvic girdle.
OBJECTIVES: The subject is based on previous study of Kinesiology, Algesiology and derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 3 and further focuses on lower extremities. The main aim is to apprehend local relations at the level of lower limb as well as global relations between trunk kinesiology and lower/upper limbs. Acquired knowledge is applied to understand underlying principles of examination and treatment techniques in the field of physiotherapy. The subject deals in detail with passive and active factors of stability of lower extremity motor segments. It gives causal definition of functional as well as structural physiology and pathology.
TEXT_PREREQUISITS: Kinesiology, Algesiology and derived Techniques of Diagnostics and Therapy 3
ASSESMENT_METHODS: 100% presence at practical seminars, 70% mark acquisition from through-term tasks, 70% mark acquisition from through-term written tests and practical exams. Final written exam (minimum of 70% successful rate) and practical exam in front of the examination board of 3 examiners. The student is not qualified for final exam in case of not fulfilling the percentage of through-term tasks, through-term written tests and practical exams. Final written test and final practical exam contributes to 50 and 50% of final evaluation respectively (A-F).
TEACHING_METHODS: Students will be exposed to the subject in a form of a lecture that will be followed by practical seminar. These seminars focus on manual techniques of examination and therapy. Students are organized in small groups. Each particular technique is first demonstrated by experienced tutors. Practical training is on peer to peer basis under close supervision of tutors and correction of precise technique.
LEARNING_OUTCOMES:
Successful completion of the subject guarantees student's ability to:
    - understand kinesiology relations within lower extremities.
    - understand principles of special examination and therapy techniques.
    - diagnose pathology, select appropriate treatment modality, execute treatment within subject extent.
    - students will also be able to educate patients incl. instructions on self-therapy.
    - the study of this subject prepares students to clinical activities with patients.
LITERATURE:
Janda, V. et al. Svalové funkční testy. Vyd. 1. Praha: Grada, 2004. 328 s. ISBN 9788024707228
        Kapandji, A.: The physiology of joints II., 2019. ISBN 9781912085606.

NAME: Physical therapy IV
TEACHERS: Toufar, V. - Komzák, M. - Srnec, J. - Dobrovolná, J.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4829 && bp4833 && bp4830 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Physical therapy position in the field of Physiotherapy (premedication). Combined therapy (general principles, therapeutical effects, methodology of application, contra/indications).
    02. Elektrodiagnostic tests – history, general principles, electrods types, ways and techniques of application, polarity, intensity.
    03. Elektrodiagnostic tests – creation of Hoorweg-Weiss´s curve and its physiological and patophysiological process, choice of area for selective stimulation.
    04. Elektrostimulation and its specifics, monopolar and bipolar application, advantages and disadvantages, frequency and time of procedure.
    05. Myostimulation and myofeedback (history, general principles, electrods types, intensity).
    06. Myostimulation (ways and techniques of application, polarity, intensity, contra/indications).
    07. Main groups of Diagnosis and ways of their treatment (therapeutic balance sheet at traumas in acute and subacute condition, in a chronic state, at functional disorders, at damage to the epidermis, during influence of spasticity).
    08. Procedures combinations with regard to an individual effects of Physical therapy.

    Practical course:
    01. Revision of electrotherapy procedures application. Choice of procedures with regard to particular effect (assignment treatments to each effect).
    02. Combined therapy – ultrasound and TENS or interferential current. CV mode. Principles, effects, an individual positioning, intensity, current density, time and frequency of procedure.
    03. Elektrodiagnostika (zjištění dráždivosti elektrod, vyhledání motorického bodu svalu a nervu).
    04. Electrodiagnostic testing (Hoorweig-Weiss curve, accommodation quotient, parameters for electrical muscle stimulation).
    05. Electrical muscle stimulation (principles, effects, an individual positioning, intensity, time and frequency of procedure).
    06. Myostimulation and myofeedback (principles, effects, an individual positioning, intensity, current density, time and frequency of procedure). Comparison of Farad´s, Neofarad´s and interferential currents subjective feelings.
    07. Practie at different workplaces with the operation of physical therapy for forteen hours.
OBJECTIVES:
Lectures:The main goal of this course is to provide basic knowledge in Physical therapy and its usage in prevention, examination and therapy of musculoskeletal and nervous system influencing all parts of human existence as a part of comprehensive rehabilitation. It´s important to meet a student with general principles of individual physical therapy parts, physiological or patophysiological organism response on their application and with possibilities of electrotherapy and combined therapy.
    Practical course: The main goal of this subject is to provide practical skills in electrotherapy especially focused on more difficult electrotherapy procedures manual application.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
Lectures: pass the final written test (min. 70 %) and then an oral exam.
    Practical course: developing a paper on the topic: News in Physical therapy (English) and a casuistry according to specified requirements. The casuistry in form of oral presentation with PC projection (in Power Point).
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lectures: frontal type of education with discussion.
    Practical course: practical training of electrotherapy procedures application "lege artis" with correction of qualified physiotherapist or rehabilitation physician. Physical therapy in practice IV includes visiting of different workplaces with the operation of physical therapy.
LITERATURE:

NAME: Sports physiotherapy 2

NAME: Ergotherapy
TEACHERS: Soporská, V. - Ševčíková, B. - Vysoký, R.
SYLLABUS:
01. Occupational therapy as a part of rehabilitation, shor term and long term occupational therapy plan.
    02. Basics of social and vocational rehabilitation, communication with the patient.
    03. Materials and technical conditions of occupational therapy.
    04. Quality of life and activities of daily living, personal assistance, assistive devices, architectural barriers.
    05. Assesment and testing in occupational therapy, ergodiagnostic.
    06. Occupational therapy in clinic disciplines.
    07. Occupational therapy in workshops.
    08. Occupational therapy in special pedagogical disciplines.
    09. The use of parts of other therapies in occupational therapy.
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the course is to introduce students to the definition of occupational therapy, its scope, objectives, methods, and contemporary concepts. It seeks to provide insight into the skills and competencies of an occupational therapist, define the occupational therapy process, and offer essential information for understanding therapeutic tools and techniques used in occupational therapy. The course focuses on occupational therapy procedures in selected clinical fields, including assessment and testing, selection of appropriate occupational therapy tools and assistive devices, and the design of targeted therapy.
ASSESMENT_METHODS: The final evaluation will be in the form of a written exam, it is necessary to meet min. 70%, and regular attendance 90%.
TEACHING_METHODS: Lectures: theoretical preparation, discussion on individual topics, presentations and videos.

NAME: Physiotherapy in clinical disciplines 4
TEACHERS: Křížová, D. - Vysoký, R. - Hnatiak, J. - Křížová, D. - Macháň, P. - Bazalová, P. - Kopečková, B.
PREREQUISITES: předp. bp4838 && bp4839 && bp4840 && bp4842 && bp4846 && bp4847 && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud ) && bozp_ok ( bozp_po_stud_fsps )
SYLLABUS:
Lectures:
    01. Introduction to strategies through methodological procedures in neurorehabilitation.
    02. Strategies of medical rehabilitation in selected neurological diseases.
    03. Rehabilitation of critically ill patients.
    04. Psychomotor development of a child, developmental kinesiology - use in rehabilitation.
    05. Pathological movement function of the child.
    06. Physiotherapeutic procedures in   DMO.
    07. Physiotherapeutic procedures in choreatic and atetoid syndrome.
    08. Physiotherapeutic procedures based on phylogenetic development - Temle Fay.
    09. Physiotherapeutic procedures based on ontogenetic development - Bobath concept.
    10. Physiotherapeutic procedures using reflex locomotion - Vojta principle reflex reflex locomotion.
    11. Reflex synergetic therapy.
    12. Hippotherapy.

    Practical excercises:
    They correspond to lectures and are delivered in a health care facility of 10 hours per week (clinics / departments of rehabilitation, neurology, spinal unit, cardiology and internal medicine, ICU).
OBJECTIVES: The aim of this course is to acquire theoretical knowledge in the field of complex medical rehabilitation in patients with neurology, in the spinal unit and in the department of intensive care (medicine) of clinical disciplines. Students are acquainted with current kinesiotherapeutic approaches, which will be subsequently applied in clinical practice.
ASSESMENT_METHODS:
The condition for successful completion of the course is:
    1. Lectures: Passing the final test (70% completion) is a prerequisite for admission to the examination.
    2. Exercise: participation in clinical practice in a healthcare facility (practical exercises) with   1 allowed absence. On the basis of these conditions the student will be confirmed participation, which is a condition for admission to the exam.
    Examination: in the form of oral examination, admission to the examination is possible only after fulfilling the above conditions.
TEACHING_METHODS:
Lectures: frontal type of education with discussion.
    Exercise: 10 hours per week (internships) during the semester in a medical facility (clinics / departments of rehabilitation, neurology, spinal unit, cardiology and internal medicine).
